channel.title: This Agile Life
channel.description: A podcast about what it's like to be Agile in the real world.
channel.itunes:summary: Agile software development is a mix of best practices and philosophical tenants. But there is a big difference between the ideal situations and what developers face in the real world. This Agile Life talks with some of the best in the business about the challenges of software engineering and how real world solutions can bring the promise of Agile methodologies to your software projects.
channel.itunes:author: John Sextro
channel.itunes:subtitle: A podcast about what it's like to be Agile in the real world.

item.title: We’re more similar than we know (Feedback Game) – 102
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, October 11th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tic, Amos King, Nate McKie and Natalie Simonsen Discussion For ThisAgileLife Episode 102, “We’re more similar than we know”, Amos, Natalie, Nate and Jason demonstrated a card-driven round-robin technique to share feedback with team members or coworkers. The outcome of the activity was that while many of you may […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, October 11th, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tic, Amos King, Nate McKie and Natalie Simonsen

Discussion

For ThisAgileLife Episode 102, “We’re more similar than we know”, Amos, Natalie, Nate and Jason demonstrated a card-driven round-robin technique to share feedback with team members or coworkers.  The outcome of the activity was that while many of you may think Amos, Natalie, Nate & Jason all think differently, they actually have more in common than perhaps you and they themselves realize.

Activities like this assist in helping self-managing teams come together and establish a stronger team mental model whereby team members have a good understanding of those they work with so that they are able to work together effectively.

The activity involved a bit of silent writing around a central question (which turned out to be not that silent on a podcast) – a series of questions were then raised to the group following the silent writing that they could respond to using the cards they had written.

Rather than explaining the technique, the hosts on ThisAgileLife participated as if they were team members so you’ll be able to hear how the technique works.  The hosts provided feedback to their teammates who work together to produce a weekly podcast.  The supplies, central question, and then follow up prompts are noted below in the event you’d like to try this activity on your team or with your colleagues.

Supplies Needed:

  • Team Members
  • 5-7 note cards per team member
  • A marker (Sharpie or similar) – using a marker is important so people can’t write that much

Central Question:

We’ll begin with a bit of silent writing, I’ve asked everyone to bring 5-7 note cards and a marker, using your marker I’d like you to write the first 5-7 attributes that come to mind about what YOU bring to our team – can be good, bad, etc – what’s important is that you focus on the FIRST things that come into your mind.

Please write each attribute on its own index card, when you run out of index cards, you’re done – you can think as much or as little as desired during this exercise, however, I urge you think go with your first thoughts vs. trying to prioritize – more than likely what comes to your mind first are the probably the most important things to discuss and get feedback on.

Round Robin Discussion Prompts:

  • Which one of your attributes do you feel you do best?
  • If you had to pick one attribute over the others, which one would it be and why?  This does not necessarily have to be the attribute that you selected as your ”best”.
  • Now let’s talk about your runner up, what the second most important attribute – what was it, why did you decide it was second?
  • Out of your attributes, which do you feel was the most recent addition to your persona – how did you become comfortable with it?
  • Is there an attribute that you think you could improve, and if so how?  Is there a member of the group that could help you with this?
  • Is there an attribute that you would like to “gift” to another member of the group?  And of course tell us why?
  • Share your any attributes that you have mentioned yet with the group – is there an attribute that you’d like to “steal” (or perhaps we should say “learn”) from someone else?

Closing:

As a final round-robin discussion, share your takeaway from this experience – what did you learn about yourself and have you identified a specific action with regard to an attribute of your persona or another member of the team’s persona.

Picks

Amos

  • Infinity Wallet
  • Fav Icon genorator
  • Join the ThisAgileLife Community

Jason

  • LIVE EVENT – St. Louis Agile Open Space II + PlayCamp – Friday, November 20, 2015
    Theme: “Practices, experiences and games to help people work together better”Come join us on the campus of Washington University in St. Louis – Additional details coming & we’re looking for a group of 50+ people to gather to discuss & discovery creative ways we can work together better – www.stlagileopenspace.com

Nate

  • Holocracy and Wall Street Journal article about Zappos
  • Hearthstone online head-to-head collectible card game

Natalie

  • Eddie Obeng: Smart failure for a fast-changing world

item.content:encoded:
Released Monday, September 21th, 2015
Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King and Lee McCauley

Discussion

  • Technical Debt 
    • Quote “Software is never finished”
    • Phases of a project
      • Race to market
        • MVP
        • MMF
      • Growth
        • New features
        • Performance & Scalability
      • Sustainment

  • John’s bottomline…”Tech debt is unavoidable. Embrace it the same way we embrace change.”

item.title: (Aug. 2015 Agile LINC) Automate, Automate – 98
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, September 6th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice and Craig Buchek Discussion ThisAgileLife hosts Craig Buchek and Jason Tice both attended the August 2015 St. Louis Agile LINC user group meeting and recorded a podcast session with user group members at the conclusion of the evening. Come hear what Melanie, Tony, Rob, Chris, Joe, Jim & […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, September 6th, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tice and Craig Buchek

Discussion

ThisAgileLife hosts Craig Buchek and Jason Tice both attended the August 2015 St. Louis Agile LINC user group meeting and recorded a podcast session with user group members at the conclusion of the evening.

Come hear what Melanie, Tony, Rob, Chris, Joe, Jim & Debbie had to say about the following topics that were discussed:

  • Automated testing
  • Flow efficiency
  • How to deal with a non-motivated team
  • Automating infrastructure deployments
  • Introducing code reviews in agile processes

Unfortunately the podcast did end abruptly as those participating had to make way for the cleaning crew (to pick up all our Post-It notes)

Picks

Jason – www.twitter.com/theagilefactor

  • GROUP – Check out St. Louis Agile LINC – this group gathers at various locations throughout the St. Louis metro area to discuss agile practices – meetings are free and open to the public and typically feature a presentation or lightning talks followed by lean coffee style breakout sessions – we just happened to record one of those sessions at their August 2015 meeting – more information and/or join via LinkedIN: https://www.linkedin.com/grp/home?gid=4881116
  • Evan Ferrante, a Tom Cruise Impersonator – recently I flew back to St. Louis sitting next to Evan (complete with Risky Business sunglasses) and we had a great chat on the flight – Check out his YouTube channel for fun (lots of Tom Cruise impersonation stuff): https://www.youtube.com/user/evanskye

item.title: (Agile 2015 Wrap-up) Podcasting at a non-sustainable pace – 97
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, August 16th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice and Natalie Simonsen Discussion Now that the Agile2015 conference has concluded, join Natalie Simonsen and Jason Tice for a round-robin discussion of their key take-aways and themes from the week long Agile2015 conference held in August 2015. Luke Hohmann inspired us in his keynote to think about […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, August 16th, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tice and Natalie Simonsen

Discussion

Now that the Agile2015 conference has concluded, join Natalie Simonsen and Jason Tice for a round-robin discussion of their key take-aways and themes from the week long Agile2015 conference held in August 2015.

  • Luke Hohmann inspired us in his keynote to think about applying the skills we have in the agile community related to problem solving, collaboration, and continuous improvement to help with challenges outside of just software development (examples could include: school funding, government, social challenges, etc).  The Agile Alliance has posted Luke’s Keynote at the following URL: http://agilealliance.org/resources/learning-center/keynote-awesome-superproblems
  • The importance of invitation over mandate with regard to adopting agile practices – people that are forced to adopt agile practices will abandon them the first opportunity that presents themselves – if you are a coach, this is a great thing to reflect on – what are you doing to “invite” people to work with you vs. “preaching” the adoption of agile practices.
  • When attending a large week-long conference like Agile2015, “Go with the flow” and challenge yourself to do something other than go to all the sessions.  Don’t get us wrong the sessions are great, but there are lots of other ways to learn, network and grow at the agile conference outside of the sessions – there’s the open jam where anyone can speak, the coaching clinic where you can get 1-on-1 advice, and even just chatting with other community members in the hallway.
  • Process and metrics are intended to serve people – processes should enable people to improve and metrics should provide insights to guide improvement without imprisoning the people doing the work.
  • We encountered several sessions at the conference that seemed to be very much focused on “selling” a particular product and/or approach that was not licensed in the public domain (Creative Commons) – we also heard similar comments to this effect during our episodes recorded at Agile2015.  Remember that the law of 2 feet is in effect at the annual Agile Alliance conference (or just about anywhere for that matter), and if you find yourself in a session where you don’t want to be “sold” to, get up and do something about it.
  • While we don’t have a standard method to assess adoption of agile methods, if a group is working to improve their agility they should be doing something to improve at all times (Kaizen, etc), something to learn and better understand how they work and what they are doing, and having fun (playing a game and/or doing a bit of Improv).
  • Bonus – the outcome of Jason’s experiment attending a 2 day agile coach camp, then a 5 day agile conference all back to back – 7 full days of immersion in “agile” was awesome, but was definitely overwhelming – 7 days came from the 2 day agile coach camp, and then the 5 day Agile2015 conference – if you’re into “high endurance learning experiences” I would recommend you put this kind of immersion on your bucket list.

Picks

Jason

  • PlayForAgile North America – Looking for your next FUN conference attend – join many of your colleagues from Agile Games, Agile2015 and/or Agile Coach Camp at PlayForAgile North America held September 11 – 13, 2015 – just outside of Toronto, Canada – Information and Registration is online: http://play4agilenorthamerica.com/
  • Bonus pick from Agile2015 – Check out Spartez – most innovative item in the Agile2015 expo hall – they have a JIRA Plugin that allow you to print physical cards from JIRA that include QR-type codes, you can then photograph your board with the cards, and their plug-in will automatically update JIRA for you – you can now have the benefits of physical kanban/cards with the precision of online / tool-generated metrics – https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.spartez.scrumprint.scrumplugin

Natalie

  • Markiplier – Check out his YouTube video and/or Twitter feed – much like the comments Luke Hohmann shared at Agile2015 he challenges us all to do something everything to make the world a better place for everyone – cool, inspiring, and make you feel good messages
    • YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pt97EVNIcrU
    • Twitter: https://twitter.com/markiplier

item.title: (Agile 2015 – Friday) I like Big Boards – 96
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Monday, August 10th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice and Natalie Simonsen Guests: Renee Troughton, Craig Smith, Stephen Vance, Troy Tuttle, Jenny Tarwater, Abby Bangser and Serge Beaumont Discussion Stephen Vance shares highlights from the multi-team agile framework he has put in place at his organization with Natalie and Renee. Abby Bangser and Jason Tice continue a […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Monday, August 10th, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tice and Natalie Simonsen
Guests: Renee Troughton, Craig Smith, Stephen Vance, Troy Tuttle, Jenny Tarwater, Abby Bangser and Serge Beaumont

Discussion

  • Stephen Vance shares highlights from the multi-team agile framework he has put in place at his organization with Natalie and Renee.
  • Abby Bangser and Jason Tice continue a discussion from Lean Coffee at Agile2015 regarding the benefits of having a full lifecycle Kanban board (product envisioning thru development thru formal testing and acceptance by the customer).
  • While discussing the benefits of “Big Boards” the excellent session that Lisa Crispin and Emma Armstrong presented on User Interface testing came up – http://sched.co/36W0
  • Next Jenny Tarwater gave props to John Krewson who did an awesome Improv workshop where attendees (including Jenny and Jason) acted out 3-4 minute Improv sketches of how waterfall could complicate simple activities in life like going to Starbucks, planning a trip to Disneyworld or dating and marriage (there are YouTube videos of these Improv sketches somewhere) but the session was AWESOME – thanks to John Krewson for allowing us to get our Improv on at Agile2015 – http://sched.co/36Q0
  • If you’ve ever played cards against humanity, Jenny Tarwater recommends “Cards for Agility” presented by Bob Payne and and Beth Miller at Agile2015 – http://sched.co/37By
  • Several present on ThisAgileLife comment on Jeff Sutherland’s “Agile Leadership Patterns” presentation and how he made several comments regarding other members of the agile community during his presentation – http://sched.co/36tB
  • Jason Tice proposes an experiment (to the organizers of Agile2016 – Bob Sarni) whereby there would be a video interview with presentation submitters prior to acceptance to confirm that their presentation is focused around learning vs. a sales pitch for a product and/or training.  BTW, the conference chair of Agile2016 is Bob Sarni – Jason mis-spoke in the recording regarding Bob Payne – there just happen to be quite a few Bob’s involved in the planning of agile conferences.
  • Serge Beaumont mentions a few of the activities that provide value in addition to the conference sessions, such as the Scrum Alliance Coaches clinic and Open Jam.  He suggests that the conference conclude with some type of “Open Space” in future years.

Serge Beaumont mentions a few of the activities that provide value in addition to the conference sessions, such as the Scrum Alliance Coaches clinic and Open Jam.  He suggests that the conference conclude with some type of “Open Space” in future years.

item.title: (Agile 2015 – Wednesday) That’s a Wiener – 95
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Friday, August 7th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice Guests: Melanie Hopwood, Dan Parker and Charles Elsner Discussion On Wednesday, August 5, 2015, ThisAgileLife celebrated a “winning” episode recorded immediately after guest Dan Parker and Jason Tice won prizes at the Agile2015 “Night at the Museums” vendor raffle event. Jason and Dan were joined by Melanie Hopwood […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Friday, August 7th, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tice
Guests: Melanie Hopwood, Dan Parker and Charles Elsner

Discussion

On Wednesday, August 5, 2015, ThisAgileLife celebrated a “winning” episode recorded immediately after guest Dan Parker and Jason Tice won prizes at the Agile2015 “Night at the Museums” vendor raffle event.  Jason and Dan were joined by Melanie Hopwood and Charles Elsner (also attending the conference) to discuss sessions they attended on Wednesday, August 5, 2015.

Jason was so happy to have invited and coached Melanie via an advocacy program within their company to give her first successful presentation at a conference (on how to test a mission-critical system used to detect weapons of mass destruction) that he gave Melanie the TV he won at the vendor raffle from the Agile Alliance.

Sessions that came up in discussion are listed below:

  • Melanie Hopwood (Testing & Quality on a Mission Critical System) – http://sched.co/36WL
  • Elisabeth Hendrickson (Stalwarts – look her up on Google for more info) – http://sched.co/3NJj
  • Janet Gregory (Agile Testing in the Enterprise) – http://sched.co/36VC
  • Mike Cottmeyer (Transforming Any Size Organization to Agile) – http://sched.co/36Pr
  • Coaching Flow (Esther Derby & Mike Lowery) – http://sched.co/36Uk
  • Jessie Shternshus (Individuals, Interactions & Improv – Keynote) – http://sched.co/3DHW
  • Wayde Stallman (50 Improv Games for Teams – presented at AgileGames2015) – www.teamfirstdevelopment.com
  • Adam Weisbart (Agile Jesters, Magicians & Clowns) – http://sched.co/36To
  • Luke Hohmann (Stalwarts – more info on Luke: www.innovationgames.com) – http://sched.co/3NKD

  • Doc List (Build Strong Teams Thru Trust & Alignment) – http://sched.co/36Qt
  • Troy Magennis (Discussion about Monte Carlo Techniques) – www.bit.ly/SimResources

During the Podcast Jason used the “Moving Motivator” cards from his session with Doc List to map out which values were most important to Dan – check out the following link (on Twitter) to see how they mapped out the cards: https://twitter.com/OneAgileDan/status/629103622001946624

BONUS PICK – Spartez (www.spartez.com) has a plug-in for JIRA that allows you to enter work items into JIRA (User Stories, etc) the print out cards with QR codes on each card – you can then put the cards on a physical board and take pictures of the board – the Agile Cards for JIRA plug-in created by Spartez will update JIRA based upon the position of cards in the photo taken.  AWESOME!!!

item.content:encoded:
Released Thursday, August 6th, 2015
Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Matt Korwel and Jason Tice
Guests: Renee Troughton, Rich Thorn, Rose Hemlock and Joe Naumann

Discussion

On Tuesday, August 4, 2015, Natalie and Jason were joined by Agile2015 conference attendees including Renee Troughton, Rich Rose Hemlock and Joe Naumann to reflect on the second day of the conference and share a few learnings from the sessions they attended.

Sessions that came up in discussion are listed below:

  • Diana Larsen & Sharon Buckmaster (Women & Men working together on agile teams) – http://sched.co/36TJ
  • Catherine Louis & Raj Mudhar (Dynamic Organization Modeling with LEGO) – http://sched.co/37rg
  • Renee Troughton (Agile Passion Fruits) – http://sched.co/36TT
  • Doc List (Conflict Management) – http://sched.co/36he
  • Lisa Crispin & Janet Gregory (Agile Testing) – http://sched.co/36VB
  • Michael McCullough & Don McGreal (Games to Learn Stuff) – http://sched.co/37K7
  • Heidi Helfand (Growing from a Team ScrumMaster to running an agile practice) – http://sched.co/36QI
  • Eric Willeke (Scaling Collaboration across teams & orgs) – http://sched.co/36Wa

We concluded by discussing an observed trend at Agile2015 regarding to increased focus on “Products” (such as Frameworks, Assessment Models, etc) and how such products could create a perception that adoption of agile is easier than it is as there is more focus on products in the “agile” industry and less on the work that people do to enable team and organizational change.

We discussed the value from frameworks and even assessment models is to “learn” from them, but then the work of agile coaches and practitioners entails determining how best to become more agile and that the tactics employed will vary from organization to organization.

Hosts: Natalie Simonsen and Jason Tice
Guests: Rose Hemlock and Joe Naumann

Discussion

On Monday, August 3, 2015, Natalie and Jason were joined by Agile2015 conference attendees Rose Hemlock and Joe Naumann to reflect on the first day of the conference and share a few learnings from the sessions they attended.

Listen in for a summary of sessions presented by Luke Hohmann (Games for solving serious problems), Jim Newkirk (Intro to Agile), Esther Derby (Rules of Change), Christopher Avery (Leadership & Self-Efficacy), David Mole (Applying Daniel Pink’s ideas from Drive to Self Managing Teams), Natalie Warnert & Brandon Carlson (Metrics Imprisonment), and of course a mention of a few of the topics mentioned at Lean Coffee.

Links to the conference schedule pages for each of the sessions discussed are provided below:

  • David Mole – http://sched.co/36Q3

item.description: Released Sunday, July 26th, 2015 Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice and John Sextro Discussion Episode 91 features a “Lean Coffee” discussion with several regular ThisAgileLife hosts (including a surprise unannounced visitor) on a variety of lean, agile and kanban topics. Lean Coffee is a meeting / discussion format created by Jim Benson (www.leancoffee.org) where […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, July 26th, 2015
Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice and John Sextro

Discussion

Episode 91 features a “Lean Coffee” discussion with several regular ThisAgileLife hosts (including a surprise unannounced visitor) on a variety of lean, agile and kanban topics.

Lean Coffee is a meeting / discussion format created by Jim Benson (www.leancoffee.org) where people gather, brainstorm discussion topics and questions on post-it notes, prioritize the topics for discussion by voting amongst the group, and then have short time-boxed discussions on the prioritized topics in the time available for discussion.  Lean Coffee is a popular morning activity at conferences, but can also be used to facilitate retrospective discussions, architecture & design sessions, team meetings, or just about any type of a group session where you’d like to create an environment that invites people to share ideas and discuss.

Just prior to recording Episode 91 in July 2015, Jason facilitated a Lean Coffee session hosted by Lean Kanban St. Louis – http://www.meetup.com/Lean-Kanban-St-Louis (sponsored by ThisAgileLife), so our podcast discussion is based on the actual topics submitted by Lean Kanban St. Louis members for which several hosts from ThisAgileLife offer insights and guidance.  Topics discussed (for about 4 minutes each) on this episode include:

  • What is the most important metric for kanban?
  • How to transition from waterfall to agile?
  • How do you break out stories in JIRA between Epics & Themes?
  • Is it possible for one team to be agile and work with a non-agile team?
  • Is it important to estimate OR make work items the same size?
  • When do stories count as WIP?
  • Requirements Gathering – when should this be done?
  • Is management the real problem? If so, what can we do?
  • How close are you to a real pull system?
  • Self Organizing Teams ???

Picks

John twitter.com/johnsextro

  • Online stopwatch for Lean Coffee style discussion (Allows you to customize the look and sound) http://www.online-stopwatch.com/custom-stopwatch/
  • Agilehood KC http://kc.agilehood.org/
  • XKCD – Duty Calls (Someone is wrong on the Internet)https://xkcd.com/386/

Jason – twitter.com/theagilefactor

  • VIDEO – Conf call in real life www.youtube.com/watch?v=DYu_bGbZiiQ
  • BONUS BOOK (for Natalie) – CTRL SHIFT (Mike Bonifer & Jessie Shternshus) 50 Games for 50 ****ing Days Like Today – http://www.amazon.com/CTRL-SHIFT-Mike-Bonifer/dp/0986296597/

Natalie – twitter.com/aussienatso

  • Spotify Engineering Culture – another Henrik Kniberg animation about the Spotify model and direction
  • This American Life Ep 56: NUMMI 2015 – A car plant in Fremont California that might have saved the U.S. car industry. In 1984, General Motors and Toyota opened NUMMI as a joint venture. Toyota showed GM the secrets of its production system: How it made cars of much higher quality and much lower cost than GM achieved. Frank Langfitt explains why GM didn’t learn the lessons—until it was too late.
  • last minute additions because we talked about estimation – http://ronjeffries.com/articles/015-jul/defined-terms/

Lee – https://twitter.com/agileatheist

  • Valve Employee Handbook – Really interesting view of a company that has 100% employee determined work.

item.title: (9th Annual State of Agile Survey) “MMWAP” – Making money with agile processes – 90
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, July 19th, 2015 Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Lee McCauley and Jason Tice Discussion On episode 90 of ThisAgileLife, join Natalie, Lee and Jason for our annual tradition of providing insights and commentary based upon the 9th annual state of agile survey administered each year by VersionOne. In this extended episode, we review the survey cover-to-cover and discuss […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, July 19th, 2015
Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Lee McCauley and Jason Tice

Discussion

On episode 90 of ThisAgileLife, join Natalie, Lee and Jason for our annual tradition of providing insights and commentary based upon the 9th annual state of agile survey administered each year by VersionOne.

In this extended episode, we review the survey cover-to-cover and discuss unknowns about how the data was collect but more importantly discuss how some of the findings in the survey point to trends or concerns within the agile community.

As our commentary did run long, feel free to take a timeout if needed as since you can imagine, Jason did go off on metrics (since the survey was based on them), and surprisingly we learned that Natalie is quite passionate about what’s going on with all the frameworks to scale agile and whether framework development aligns to the ideals of the agile community.

Highlights include:

  • Questioning the merit of the survey findings citing unknowns and inconsistencies in the reported demographics of the survey respondents.
  • Hypothesizing on what kind of criteria respondents used to determine if their organization “had adopted agile” and for which Natalie, Lee and Jason offer their own ideas about how to determine if agile has been adopted.
  • Questions surrounding the validity of the data for the benefits of adoption agile when compared with real agile transformation experiences – while many respondents reported the ability to deliver faster and change priorities, we have experienced that during initial adoption of agile methods, product delivery may actually slow and changing priorities can really hurt.
  • Thoughts that some on “distributed teams” (highlighted in the survey) using being distributed as an excuse to not engage in face-to-face communication when they are plenty of tools and technologies available to make face-to-face communication feasible in nearly all circumstances as recommended by the agile manifesto.
  • A discussion regarding the pros & cons regarding the prevalence of adopting “Scrum” vs. other methodologies cited in the survey data.
  • Sharing ideas on the rather consistent data from year to year regarding the adoption of specific agile practices – if the agile community is growing and maturing as has been proposed, why do we not see corresponding upward trends across the adoption of all agile practices listed.
  • Could there be a correlation between failed agile projects and the high percentage of organizations that are unable to change their culture to allow for activities necessary for agile success including sharing work, shifting away from promoting heros, and allowing learn from failure (meaning it is OK to fail).
  • An alarming trend and hypothesis that many are questioning the “value” of agile because we aren’t using precise metrics to determine success when there are opportunities to do so within agile software development projects.
  • Questions and concerns regarding if the increasing number of competing frameworks to scale agile (of which several have interesting acronyms: SAFe, LeSS, RAGE) are providing effective guidance to the community or are they creating more confusion citing the there is much overlap between practices in the various frameworks to scale agile.
  • A really interesting observation that given the growth of the DevOps community, agile practices & tools supportive of DevOps such as Automated Build tools, and Continuous Deployment tools have actually seen decreased usage in the last year – one would think use of such tools should have grown significantly as more organizations have reported to have achieved Continuous Deployment.
  • And of course, our thoughts on the continued domination of Microsoft Excel as the #1 tool used to support agile projects.

Picks

Jason – twitter.com/theagilefactor

  • SURVEY – The VersionOne 9th Annual State of Agile Survey – go download the survey, review it and give us your thoughts on our length and comprehensive analysis –  http://info.versionone.com/state-of-agile-development-survey-ninth.html
  • THANKS – Thanks to VersionOne for compiling the annual state of agile survey as it certainly does provide insights for which we can reflect, learn and grow as a community – www.versionone.com

Natalie – twitter.com/aussienatso

  • TOOL – Feature Mapping tool – https://www.featuremap.co/
  • VIDEO – Something specifically for Jason (NO not Jason, it’s V1 that said StoryMapping is going down in popularity) (But you used it so you are just as bad) – https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Tqd80aAnlA

Lee – https://twitter.com/agileatheist

  • INSIGHTS – Developing for Android: Introduction A great series of articles focusing on Android development best practices.

item.title: (Wishful Planning) Don’t be an agile hoarder – 89
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, July 12th, 2015 Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Nate McKie and Jason Tice Discussion Join Natalie, Nate and Jason for a discussion about “Wishful planning” on ThisAgileLife Episode 89. Jason shares some recent work he did as supporting the Product Owner role where he was wondering how many stories he should create for a new product story […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, July 12th, 2015
Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Nate McKie and Jason Tice

Discussion

Join Natalie, Nate and Jason for a discussion about “Wishful planning” on ThisAgileLife Episode 89.

Jason shares some recent work he did as supporting the Product Owner role where he was wondering how many stories he should create for a new product story map following a multi-day brainstorming session.  Nate and Natalie offer feedback and all share insights and practices to determine how long your backlog should be, and also how to tell if your current backlog is too long.

Related to this discussion, ThisAgileLife Episode 89 runs down some recent suggestions from Gil Broza on how to not fall victim to wishful planning on agile projects.  Natalie, Nate and Jason offer insights, examples, and simple practices on some of the examples that Gil touched on including:

  • Understand outcome and purpose – of every piece of work
  • Prioritize your constraints – at the beginning
  • Estimate collaborative – especially on big items
  • Spend time replanning – not just revisiting schedules

While wrapping things up, Jason mentioned Agile2015 to be held in August 2015 in Washington, DC – several hosts from ThisAgileLife will be attending including Natalie, Matt Korwel, and Jason, so we look forward to seeing many of our listeners in DC – Tweet us if you’ll be there.

References (with links) mentioned during the show:

  • VIDEO – Product Ownership in a Nutshell – a 15 minute visual summary of what agile is that anyone can understand by Henrik Kniberg https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=502ILHjX9EE
  • GAME – GetKanban – an immersive kanban simulation that teaches the practices and mechanics of Kanban by Russell Healey – www.getkanban.com
  • ARTICLE – “Wishful Planning and Agile” – Insights from Gil Broza about wishful planning, including how to recognize it and the practices to avoid it that we discussed on the episode – http://icont.ac/301Ig

Picks

Nate – twitter.com/natemckie

  • Apple’s beta program
  • Planet Money podcast

Jason – twitter.com/theagilefactor

  • LIVE EVENT – Agile2015 – August 3-7, 2015 in Washington, DC – http://agile2015.agillealliance.org
    • We’re still a few weeks out, so if you really want to you can probably figure out a way to get to Agile2015
    • If you’re going to be there come play FireDice with me on Friday morning, August 7 – you are guaranteed to not fall asleep the morning after the party if you come play FireDice
    • If you’re NOT going to Agile2015, follow #agile2015 on Twitter to gain insights and ideas from the conference from anywhere!
    • Natalie, Matt and Jason from ThisAgileLife will be at Agile2015 – come hang out with us
  • CHARITY – The Goodwill Rule – if you have something that you haven’t touched in 6+ months (and it isn’t a seasonal item), then you probably don’t need it, donate it to Goodwill or another charity to help someone else out.

item.itunes:summary: Released Sunday, July 12th, 2015 Hosts: Natalie Simonsen, Nate McKie and Jason Tice Discussion Join Natalie, Nate and Jason for a discussion about “Wishful planning” on ThisAgileLife Episode 89. Jason shares some recent work he did as supporting the Product Owner role where he was wondering how many stories he should create for a new product story map following a multi-day brainstorming session.  Nate and Natalie offer feedback and all share insights and practices to determine how long your backlog should be, and also how to tell if your current backlog is too long. Related to this discussion, ThisAgileLife Episode 89 runs down some recent suggestions from Gil Broza on how to not fall victim to wishful planning on agile projects.  Natalie, Nate and Jason offer insights, examples, and simple practices on some of the examples that Gil touched on including: Understand outcome and purpose - of every piece of work Prioritize your constraints - at the beginning Estimate collaborative - especially on big items Spend time replanning - not just revisiting schedules While wrapping things up, Jason mentioned Agile2015 to be held in August 2015 in Washington, DC - several hosts from ThisAgileLife will be attending including Natalie, Matt Korwel, and Jason, so we look forward to seeing many of our listeners in DC - Tweet us if you’ll be there. References (with links) mentioned during the show: VIDEO - Product Ownership in a Nutshell - a 15 minute visual summary of what agile is that anyone can understand by Henrik Kniberg https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=502ILHjX9EE GAME - GetKanban - an immersive kanban simulation that teaches the practices and mechanics of Kanban by Russell Healey - www.getkanban.com ARTICLE - “Wishful Planning and Agile” - Insights from Gil Broza about wishful planning, including how to recognize it and the practices to avoid it that we discussed on the episode - http://icont.ac/301Ig Picks Nate - twitter.com/natemckie Apple’s beta program Planet Money podcast Jason - twitter.com/theagilefactor LIVE EVENT - Agile2015 - August 3-7, 2015 in Washington, DC - http://agile2015.agillealliance.org We’re still a few weeks out, so if you really want to you can probably figure out a way to get to Agile2015 If you’re going to be there come play FireDice with me on Friday morning, August 7 - you are guaranteed to not fall asleep the morning after the party if you come play FireDice If you’re NOT going to Agile2015, follow #agile2015 on Twitter to gain insights and ideas from the conference from anywhere! item.title: (Change Leadership) A Sense of Urgency – Ep. 87
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, June 14th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice, Craig Buchek and Lee McCauley Discussion On Episode 87 of ThisAgileLife, join Lee, Craig and Jason for a discussion on John Kotter’s ideas about “Change Leadership” and how this concept relates to agile transformation. Kotter’s work outlines an eight-step process to enable organizational change by building influence rather than mandate, and […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, June 14th, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tice, Craig Buchek and Lee McCauley

Discussion

On Episode 87 of ThisAgileLife, join Lee, Craig and Jason for a discussion on John Kotter’s ideas about “Change Leadership” and how this concept relates to agile transformation.

Kotter’s work outlines an eight-step process to enable organizational change by building influence rather than mandate, and as is discussed on the episode, several of our hosts have had experience applying Kotter’s process or several steps within it.

Craig, Lee and Jason engage in a lengthy discussion to talk through each of the 8 steps and share experiences and insights related to each step in their prior activities to support the adoption of agile methods in various organizations.

The key steps of Kotter’s Change Leadership process are summarized below:

#1 – Create a sense of urgency – Craft and use a significant opportunity as a means for exciting people to sign up to change their organization.

#2 – Build a guiding coalition – Assemble a group with the power and energy to lead and support a collaborative change effort.

#3 – Form a strategic vision and initiatives – Shape a vision to help steer the change effort and develop strategic initiatives to achieve that vision.

#4 – Enlist a volunteer army – Raise a large force of people who are ready, willing and urgent to drive change.

#5 – Enable action by removing barriers – Remove obstacles to change, change systems or structures that pose threats to the achievement of the vision.

#6 – Generate short term wins – Consistently produce, track, evaluate and celebrate volumes of small and large accomplishments – and correlate them to results.

#7 – Sustain acceleration – Use increasing credibility to change systems, structures and policies that don’t align with the vision; hire, promote and develop employees who can implement the vision; reinvigorate the process with new projects, themes and volunteers.

#8 – Institute Change – Articulate the connections between the new behaviors and organizational success, and develop the means to ensure leadership development and succession.
Additional insights about Kotter’s 8-step process for organizational change and “Change Leadership is available at: http://www.kotterinternational.com/the-8-step-process-for-leading-change/

Picks

Craig – @CraigBuchek

  • Two comics showing the difference between a boss and a leader.
  • Derek Sivers’ TED Talk on How to Start A Movement

Jason – @theagilefactor

  • BOOK – Leading Change (John Kotter) – the updated book by the creator of the “Change Leadership” concept
  • BOOK – The Culture Game: Tools for the Agile Manager (Dan Mezick) – useful tools for agile manager and talks about change by influence rather than mandate
  • THANKS – to all the ThisAgileLife fans that attended Big Apple Scrum Day and said HI – Tweet us with ideas and/or questions from Big Apple Scrum Day and we’ll talk about them on future episodes of ThisAgileLife.
  • METRICS – Live from New York, it’s 30+ metrics for agile & scrum teams – Thanks to the organizers of the inaugural Big Apple Scrum Day in June 2015 for the chance to share the ideas with Scrum & agile practitioners in New York City – download the presentation and reference sheet at the link above.

Lee – @agileatheist

  • Asking good questions
  • Gateway to Reason

item.title: (Pros/Cons of Testing & TDD) The Price is Right – Ep. 83
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, May 3rd, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice and Craig Buchek Discussion Craig wanted to provide some feedback on a few of our recent topics, where he had been called out: When should we do TDD? (Episode 78) Craig said that we should only do testing or TDD when the benefits outweigh the costs. Unfortunately, we usually […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, May 3rd, 2015
Hosts: Jason Tice and Craig Buchek

Discussion

Craig wanted to provide some feedback on a few of our recent topics, where he had been called out:

When should we do TDD? (Episode 78)

Craig said that we should only do testing or TDD when the benefits outweigh the costs. Unfortunately, we usually greatly underestimate the benefits. And the costs often seem high at first, because it takes some time to get good at writing automated tests. Not to mention that both the costs and the benefits are usually hard to measure.

Craig asked what is the cost of writing automated tests? He found he had asked the question before and recorded the answers (inasmuch as we have them) to his blog:

So we don’t have much science on TDD. But we do have some. Here’s a collection of several: StudiesOfTestDrivenDevelopment. And here’s one that explicitly looks are the difference between test-first and test-last: Does Test-Driven Development Really Improve Software Design Quality? What do these tell us? They tell us that TDD costs us about 10-30% in short-term productivity, reduces bugs by 30-90%, and decreases code complexity by about 30%. As Code Complete tells us (in section 20.5, with studies to back it up), improving quality reduces development costs. So, like most Agile practices, this is a case where spending a bit more time in the short term leads to time savings in the long term.

A couple scenarios where Craig thinks that it might make sense to not write tests:
When we’re more concerned about time to market than quality. We agreed that this is almost always a mistake. But sometimes that’s the best knowledge we have to work with at the time we make that decision.
When there’s no test framework for the situation you’re testing. This might be a new language or framework that you’re working with. More likely it’s a complex API that you have to mock out. So that could increase the cost of automated testing so as to outweigh the benefits — especially on a short project. OR Jason mentioned creating a test framework for an emerging technology / language could have long-term benefits in terms of future cost-savings and intangible benefits like gaining influence — where there’s a will there’s a way!

But these situations should not be common; they’re edge cases. In almost all cases, all the This Agile Life hosts agree that TDD is the right thing to do.

Amos mentioned that Craig told him to never call a vote unless you already know the outcome. (Episode 78)

Craig said he usually reserves this for when he’s coaching a team and wants to guide them to an outcome that he’s quite certain is the right direction — so something major like pair programming or TDD. In most circumstances, he’d let the team make their own decisions without any added influence.

Jason mentioned taking a concurrence vote as another way to achieve similar outcomes. Craig pointed out that this employs some amount of psychological and social influence as well.

 

Picks

Jason

  • BOOK – Business Model You – Ideas to apply the business model canvas to reinvert your career
  • LIVE EVENT – Come hang out at Lean Kanban North America for a 3 hour workshop on learning games based on Lean & Kanban principles – June 8/9/10 in Miami Beach, FL

Craig

  • Data v Awareness by Jessica Kerr, about recording throughout the week what’s bugging people, and making a word cloud to talk about at retro
  • The Engineer’s Lament by Malcolm Gladwell (in the New Yorker)

item.description: Released Sunday, April 19th, 2015 Hosts: Matt Korwell, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice and special guest Ryan Ripley Discussion On Episode 81 of ThisAgileLife, your agile coaches at ThisAgileLife completed yet another experiment to improve the Podcast. We invited Ryan Ripley (@ryanripley) a regular listener to join us to share some insights from his presentation at the 2015 Agile Indy conference entitled “The Scrum […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, April 19th, 2015

Hosts: Matt Korwell, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice and special guest Ryan Ripley

Discussion

On Episode 81 of ThisAgileLife, your agile coaches at ThisAgileLife completed yet another experiment to improve the Podcast. We invited Ryan Ripley (@ryanripley) a regular listener to join us to share some insights from his presentation at the 2015 Agile Indy conference entitled “The Scrum Master IS The Impediment”

Ryan talked through his observations and experiences with several common anti-patterns that reduce the effectiveness of the ScrumMaster role – these included:

  • The ScrumMaster serving as a Dictator
  • The team being aided by a SuperHero ScrumMaster
  • The ScrumMaster who becomes too prescriptive in how to help a team
  • And lastly, the ScrumMaster who serves as the team’s technical expert

Join as Lee, Matt and Jason engage in a lively conversation with Ryan on these ScrumMaster anti-patterns, including why they occur, how they are harmful to the team, and how to avoid them – you’ll even get to enjoy a few agile confessions as some of our ThisAgileLife coaches admit to falling victim to these anti-patterns themselves.

Thanks again to Ryan for sharing his insights and participating in ThisAgileLife Episode 80.

Picks

Matt

  • http://mcfunley.com/choose-boring-technology
  • https://42floors.com/blog/startups/thirty-percent-feedback
  • http://blog.codinghorror.com/a-modest-proposal-for-the-copy-and-paste-school-of-code-reuse/

Lee

Jason

item.itunes:summary: Released Sunday, April 19th, 2015 Hosts: Matt Korwell, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice and special guest Ryan Ripley Discussion On Episode 81 of ThisAgileLife, your agile coaches at ThisAgileLife completed yet another experiment to improve the Podcast. We invited Ryan Ripley (@ryanripley) a regular listener to join us to share some insights from his presentation at the 2015 Agile Indy conference entitled “The Scrum Master IS The Impediment” Ryan talked through his observations and experiences with several common anti-patterns that reduce the effectiveness of the ScrumMaster role - these included: The ScrumMaster serving as a Dictator The team being aided by a SuperHero ScrumMaster The ScrumMaster who becomes too prescriptive in how to help a team And lastly, the ScrumMaster who serves as the team’s technical expert Join as Lee, Matt and Jason engage in a lively conversation with Ryan on these ScrumMaster anti-patterns, including why they occur, how they are harmful to the team, and how to avoid them - you’ll even get to enjoy a few agile confessions as some of our ThisAgileLife coaches admit to falling victim to these anti-patterns themselves. Thanks again to Ryan for sharing his insights and participating in ThisAgileLife Episode 80. You may be surprised with what they have to say, and best of all Elvis (yes, Elvis […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, April 12th, 2015

Hosts: Lee McCauley, Jason Tice and Amos King

Discussion

Episode 80 of “This Agile Life” starts off with a bang as Amos, Lee and Jason discussion times when you shouldn’t test your code.  You may be surprised with what they have to say, and best of all Elvis (yes, Elvis Presley) makes a cameo appearance on “This Agile Life” to share his ideas about Test Driven Development.

Next Amos wanted to try a taste test from “The Agile Buffet” discussed back on Episode 78, so on the spot Amos challenged Jason and Lee to describe Test Driven Development as a buffet item.  Amos got to enjoy a mash-up of teaching your kids to their vegetables (Lee), learning to eat with Chopsticks (Jason), and then teaching a baby to eat with a fork (Lee).  Listen in and you can decide if Jason’s and Lee’s description tastes anything like your TDD practice.

Finally, we completed a “first ever” experiment of having a random listener join the podcast for an on-air coaching clinic regarding current challenges they are having.  Listener Mark shares his team is struggling to achieve consensus between doing things the right way vs. getting them done as quickly – Listen in as Amos, Jason, and Lee share some advice for Mark.

Picks

Lee

  • Is TDD Dead? A series of conversations between Kent Beck, David Heinemeier Hansson, and Martin Fowler on the topic of Test-Driven Development (TDD) and its impact upon software design.
  • The Ultimate Dad Joke Duel – CollegeHumor

Jason

  • Thanks to the organizers of Agile Denver for their awesome Mile High Agile conference in April 2015.
  • Gil Broza – Your Daily Standup Revitalizer – http://dailystandup.3pvantage.com
  • LIVE EVENT – STL Agile Open Space – Friday, April 17, 2015 – Don’t delay – Sign Up Today –  http://www.stlagileopenspace.com

Mark Katerberg:

  • iamthefold.com

Amos

  • User groups – Check out a local user group – you’ll be amazed at what you can learn – Amos coordinates the St. Louis Ruby Users Group – http://www.meetup.com/stlruby/
  • http://letitcrash.com/ – Love their design

item.title: Ep. 78 – Squirrels (Team Practices)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, March 29th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice, Natalie Simonsen, Matt Korwel, Lee McCauley and Craig Buchek Discussion Episode 78 began with our 5 ThisAgileLife hosts (Lee, Craig, Natalie, Matt & Jason) playing a round-robin game to each share something they see people adopting agile doing that we believe could be improved – this is a […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, March 29th, 2015

Hosts: Jason Tice, Natalie Simonsen, Matt Korwel, Lee McCauley and Craig Buchek

Discussion

Episode 78 began with our 5 ThisAgileLife hosts (Lee, Craig, Natalie, Matt & Jason) playing a round-robin game to each share something they see people adopting agile doing that we believe could be improved – this is a game you could play with your team at your next retrospective.  The following ideas (all awesome podcast topics) were shared:

  • People trying to adopt too many practices at once (we called this the agile buffet)
  • Teams not having a good understanding of the project / product vision
  • Nobody on their team believing in the Prime Directive for Retrospectives
  • Struggling to maintain a good balance between individuals & interactions vs. processes & tools
  • Using change management vs. change leadership to adopt agile methods

Again these were all awesome ideas to discuss – the 5 hosts voted quickly to discuss the “agile buffet” problem shared by Lee.

We determined that sometimes teams adopt practices not knowing fully why to consider them and what specific value / benefit they provide to the team.  Teams can also fall victim to adopting multiple practices that ultimately support the same outcome which can slow things down.

In the middle of discussion about adopting practices, we briefly highlighted (and of course debated) the pros/cons of waiting to discuss challenges at a scheduled team retrospective vs. an on-demand improvement session (like a turn-around meeting).

Back on the agile buffet topic, we shared some ideas to help teams understand how best to measure improvements that are provided by adopting specific practices, and also provided some insights on what to do if management shows up with a nice “big picture” (since we know there are a few of those floating around out there) and asks that teams adopt all the practices in the big picture at the same time.

Lee concluded our discussion (since he shared the “agile buffet” idea in our initial round robin) challenging everyone to ask “why” specific practices are being used or considered, to conduct experiments to see which practices work best for your team, to ensure you know how measure any practices adopted are providing sufficient value, and that everyone out there can have this discussion on all this in their next team retrospective.

Picks

Lee

  • Kids Learn to Code in Java through modding Minecraft: http://www.wired.com/2014/08/learntomod/ by Klint Finley and http://www.youthdigital.com/mod-design-1-code-with-minecraft.html

Craig

  • Pairing with Junior Developers by Sarah Mei
  • Packer – builds server images
  • Digital Ocean hosting

Natalie

  • The Phoenix Project: A Novel about IT, DevOps, and Helping Your Business Win – http://www.amazon.com/The-Phoenix-Project-Helping-Business/dp/0988262592

Matt

  • https://www.kateheddleston.com/blog/argument-cultures-and-unregulated-aggression
  • http://qualityisspeed.blogspot.com/2014/08/why-i-dont-teach-solid.html
  • http://www.seattlecoderdojo.com/ – Teaching kids to code, one saturday at a time
  • https://chocolatey.org/ windows powershell package manager

Jason

  • Listen to old episodes of ThisAgileLife (you’ll be amazed what you can learn) – www.thisagilelife.com
  • Looking for a building conducive to agile software development – here’s an old elementary school building (The Wright School – 10601 Clayton Road – Frontenac, MO) for sale just outside St. Louis, Missouri (put a few dev teams in each classroom and there’s a playground out back – so much fun) – https://www.google.com/maps/@38.633074,-90.413069,3a,75y,90t/data=!3m4!1e1!3m2!1sbzWbsqcM8Q1DEkmnriLBhA!2e0
  • LIVE EVENT in St. Louis, MO – An evening with Doug Dockery from Rally software – “Maximizing the value we deliver” – April 9, 2015 – Free – Register online: http://www.meetup.com/Lean-Kanban-St-Louis/events/221183758/
  • LIVE EVENT in St. Louis, MO – The first full day public open space on agile – April 17, 2015 – small registration fee – more info & register online: www.stlagileopenspace.com
  • LIVE EVENT & Last Minute – come learn about gamification of performance reviews at Mile High Agile on Friday, 4/3/2015 in Denver, CO – http://milehighagile2015.agiledenver.org/

item.title: Ep. 75 – Sass Factor (Managing Up)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, March 8th, 2015 Hosts: John Sextro, Craig Buchek and Jason Tice Special Guest: Natalie Simonsen Discussion Managing Up What is Managing Up – a Definition thanks to Wikipedia: Managing up and managing down is studied as part of management studies as how a middle manager should effectively deal with his or her manager and […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, March 8th, 2015

Hosts: John Sextro, Craig Buchek and Jason Tice
Special Guest: Natalie Simonsen

Discussion

Managing Up

What is Managing Up – a Definition thanks to Wikipedia:

Managing up and managing down is studied as part of management studies as how a middle manager should effectively deal with his or her manager and with his or her subordinates. Additionally, managing up on its own may be a useful skill for a subordinate who in turn does not manage anyone. It is generally considered to be distinct from “sucking up” or “kissing up” to the manager and “kicking down” to subordinates as it involves benign above board influencing rather than underhand manipulation.

Dealing with executive leadership just wants to see results.

Showing progress via working software

How to deal with long term roadmap needs.

  • Burn up value chart
  • Planning quote (Insert later)
  • Vision from roadmap for the team
  • Lean canvas
  • Product “Cereal Box”
  • Science Fair approach

How to deal with, “I don’t get it.”

  • Probe the question, “Why don’t you get it.”
  • Explain in deep detail
  • Setup time with the person offline to address their concerns.
  • Does “I don’t get it” fail the safety check in transparency.

Picks

Natalie

  • Lootcrate
  • Nerdblock

John

  • Influence Without Authority (2nd Edition)

Jason

  • A few suggestions from our friends at Thoughtworks: “10 Ways to Improve Your Pairing Experience”
  • Thanks to “The Agile Roundup” a few interesting thoughts on what happens when process junkies are parents – this is sounds like a few of our prior chats on ThisAgileLife
  • Looking for Agile Enlightenment – check this Twitter feed out (trust me – you’ll laugh): https://twitter.com/agileborat
  • Follow @ThisAgileLife (or @theagilefactor) on Twitter for Outtakes

Craig

  • ServerSpec – TDD your server configuration
  • Atom Pair – drive Atom text editor with 2 (or more) people
  • Agile Memes on Twitter
  • Prediction: Atom Text more popular than Sublime Text in 2 years.

item.title: Ep. 74 – Perfect Rundown (Working the Board)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, March 1st, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice, Nate McKie and Lee McCauley Discussion Note: Episode 74 was interrupted just after it got started by Lee’s “changing his headphone jack” experiment – you may hear a bit of line-noise (sounds like a jet engine) but we then quickly resolved it and resumed the episode – thanks […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, March 1st, 2015

Hosts: Jason Tice, Nate McKie and Lee McCauley

Discussion

Note: Episode 74 was interrupted just after it got started by Lee’s “changing his headphone jack” experiment – you may hear a bit of line-noise (sounds like a jet engine) but we then quickly resolved it and resumed the episode – thanks for your patience

Two questions frequently asked on agile teams submitted by two of our great listeners:

  • How to get people to only do work that is on the work board? (Submitted by Dawn V)
  • Ensure all team members are allowed to add cards to the board, including splitting stories if so desired.
  • Find out why people aren’t spending all their time working on the board – are they having to support another system / team?
  • If a team feels they can’t put technical debt work up on the board, discuss and create working agreements allowing the team to do so and ensure technical debt stories also prioritized with user stories for the business.
  • It’s important to stay focused on the board as it drives the “system” of the team – the board helps to determine metrics used to establish goals and these metrics become less accurate if they don’t encompass all of the team’s work – if a team works off the board then you don’t know what the true capacity of the team is.
  • Use the board to encourage the whole team approach – do something visual to encourage all teams members to support cards in all states as they are pulled across the board.
  • MobProgramming is an alternative approach which could help Dawn out – in Mobbing everyone works together on a single workstation with a single screen.

What can managers do to help out an agile team (Submitted by Ryan R)

  • Managers can serve the team by working with the team to determine the boundary of the team’s self organization – once this boundary is defined, managers allow the team to self-organize within bounds.
  • Likewise, managers listen for ways they can support the team when asked by the team, and they also work to avoid and eliminate impediments outside of the team’s boundary of self-organization.
  • If you’re a manager of a team, consider asking the teams you support / manage to write “Job Stories” for you – what job are they hiring/asking you to do for them – then you can prioritize those job stories and work on them to provide value / support to the team.
  • A key responsibility of a manager / leader is to create a “safe” environment for the team to work in – this includes clearly defining who is on/off the team, what other teams/function support the team, and have a feedback system to engage properly with the team to provide assistance proactively.

Picks

Lee

    • Screenhero, a great screen sharing application specifically designed for pair programming. Now part of Slack.

Jason

    • Management 3.0 by Jurgen Apello – a great book for management and executive support of agile teams
    • The idea of “Jobs to be Done” and “Job Stories” – compliments of Dr. Clayton Christensen – check out a video about a milkshake that serves as the motivation for job stories
    • MileHileAgile 2015 – Come get “High” with TheAgileFactor in Denver on April 3, 2015 as we talk more about how to improve performance reviews to align to Agile Values using Visual Collaboration Games
    • ThisAgileLife Lightning Talks – Join your favorite ThisAgileLife hosts on a future episode as each present a Lightning Talk – www.thisagilelife.com

Nate

    • Pecha Kucha
    • Microsoft Outlook for iOS
item.itunes:subtitle: Released Sunday, March 1st, 2015 - Hosts: Jason Tice, Nate McKie and Lee McCauley Discussion Note: Episode 74 was interrupted just after it got started by Lee’s “changing his headphone jack” experiment - you may hear a bit of line-noise (sounds like...
item.itunes:summary: Released Sunday, March 1st, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice, Nate McKie and Lee McCauley Discussion Note: Episode 74 was interrupted just after it got started by Lee’s “changing his headphone jack” experiment - you may hear a bit of line-noise (sounds like a jet engine) but we then quickly resolved it and resumed the episode - thanks for your patience Two questions frequently asked on agile teams submitted by two of our great listeners: How to get people to only do work that is on the work board? (Submitted by Dawn V) Ensure all team members are allowed to add cards to the board, including splitting stories if so desired. Find out why people aren’t spending all their time working on the board - are they having to support another system / team? If a team feels they can’t put technical debt work up on the board, discuss and create working agreements allowing the team to do so and ensure technical debt stories also prioritized with user stories for the business. It’s important to stay focused on the board as it drives the “system” of the team - the board helps to determine metrics used to establish goals and these metrics become less accurate if they don’t encompass all of the team’s work - if a team works off the board then you don’t know what the true capacity of the team is. Use the board to encourage the whole team approach - do something visual to encourage all teams members to support cards in all states as they are pulled across the board. MobProgramming is an alternative approach which could help Dawn out - in Mobbing everyone works together on a single workstation with a single screen. What can managers do to help out an agile team (Submitted by Ryan R) Managers can serve the team by working with the team to determine the boundary of the team’s self organization - once this boundary is defined, managers allow the team to self-organize within bounds. Likewise, managers listen for ways they can support the team when asked by the team, and they also work to avoid and eliminate impediments outside of the team’s boundary of self-organization. If you’re a manager of a team, consider asking the teams you support / manage to write “Job Stories” for you - what job are they hiring/asking you to do for them - then you can prioritize those job stories and work on them to provide value / support to the team. A key responsibility of a manager / leader is to create a “safe” environment for the team to work in - this includes clearly defining who is on/off the team, what other teams/function support the team, and have a feedback system to engage properly with the team to provide assistance proactively. Picks Lee Screenhero, a great screen sharing application specifically designed for pair programming. Now part of Slack. Jason Management 3.0 by Jurgen Apello - a great book for management and executive support of agile teams The idea of “Jobs to be Done” and “Job Stories” - compliments of Dr. Clayton Christensen - check out a video about a milkshake that serves as the motivation for job stories MileHileAgile 2015 - Come get “High” with TheAgileFactor in Denver on April 3, 2015 as we talk more about how to improve performance reviews to align to Agile Values using Visual Collaboration Games ThisAgileLife Lightning Talks - Join your favorite ThisAgileLife hosts on a future episode as each present a Lightning Talk - www.thisagilelife.com

item.title: Ep. 73 – In a World (No BAs / No SMs)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, February 15th, 2015 Hosts: Amos King and John Sextro Discussion We don’t need Scrum Masters and Business Analysts In the future agile teams will optimize around 2 roles, PO and Engineer. Over the past 40 years large corporations have excelled at turning people into highly specialized workers. The work done by scrum masters […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, February 15th, 2015

Hosts: Amos King and John Sextro

Discussion

We don’t need Scrum Masters and Business Analysts

In the future agile teams will optimize around 2 roles, PO and Engineer.  Over the past 40 years large corporations have excelled at turning people into highly specialized workers.

The work done by scrum masters and business analysts can be absorbed by engineers. I challenge you to come up with a single job responsibility that can’t be done by an engineer.

When you have a team made entirely of engineers that embrace the “whole team” approach you eliminate bottlenecks within the team and will improve efficiency.

Knowledge workers DO NOT require supervision

How to transition

  • Change hiring profile to focus equally on soft skills and technical skills with a premium placed on flexibility/adaptability
  • Initiate new teams with engineers only
  • Offer opportunities for scrum masters and business analysts to transition to engineer roles
  • Offer opportunities for scrum masters and business analysts to transition to coaching roles
  • Leverage coaches to mentor teams as they transition
  • Avoid the tendency to want to put someone “in charge”.  You don’t need a single point of contact.

Picks

Amos

  • f.lux
  • boredom – New Tech City

John

  • DotStorming

The code coding practices technical debt agile processes collaboration quality All these things require time to make better […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, February 1st, 2015

Video Link

Hosts: Jason Tice, John Sextro, Lee McCauley and Craig Buchek

Discussion

Topics contributed by Chris Morgan. Thank you!

  • How much time is considered healthy for an agile team to spend improving themselves?
    • The code
    • coding practices
    • technical debt
    • agile processes
    • collaboration
    • quality

All these things require time to make better so we can go faster but the perception is that doing those things takes the team away from developing new features and slows them down.

Lee

  • What If, by Randall Munroe. (creator of xkcd.com) Serious scientific answers to absurd hypothetical questions

item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, Janury 11th, 2015

Hosts: Jason Tice, John Sextro and Amos King

Discussion

Topics contributed by Rich Thorn and Firoj Shaikh. Thank you!

  • Driving teams to small stories
    • Cards
    • “Twitter sized” stories
    • Constrain to ½ day to 1 day
  • How business stories and development stories relate with each other?
    • Not embracing whole team approach
    • Development stories are sub-stories for the business stories
  • What is the best way to organize stories?
    • How to prioritize to work most effectively?
      • Leverage business
  • How much time developers should spend on analysis?
    • As much as is necessary to implement the story
    • T-shaped people
    • Whole team approach

Picks

Lee

  • MadeWithCode, a community to encourage girls to learn computer programming and resources to build the skills early.

John

  • Ninjevade, great new game for Android and iOS developed by my friend Matt Burton.
  • Working with Legacy Code, by Michael Feathers

Jason

  • Designing Features Using Job Stories (an emerging practice similiar yet different to user stories) – http://blog.intercom.io/using-job-stories-design-features-ui-ux/ – read this and then listen for us to talk about Job Stories on a future episode of ThisAgileLife.

item.title: Ep. 70 – Horrible Waste of Space (Open Space Floor Plans)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, Janury 11th, 2015 Hosts: Jason Tice, John Sextro and Amos King Discussion People that responded to my email Marcelo Magallon – prefers the semi-private partitions Rich Thorn – cave and common design is the right way to go. Give your people the choice The Open-Office Trap published in the New Yorker, by Maria Konnikova 1997 – […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, Janury 11th, 2015

Hosts: Jason Tice, John Sextro and Amos King

Discussion

People that responded to my email

  • Marcelo Magallon – prefers the semi-private partitions
  • Rich Thorn – cave and common design is the right way to go. Give your people the choice
  • The Open-Office Trap published in the New Yorker, by Maria Konnikova
    • 1997 – The University of Calgary study (before, 4 weeks after and 6 months after)
      • Disruptive, stressful, cumbersome, dissatisfied, resentful
      • Productivity fell
    • 2005 Study
      • When workers couldn’t change the way that things looked, adjust the lighting and temperature, or choose how to conduct meetings, spirits plummeted.
  • Cubicles, they suck
    • False sense of privacy
    • They don’t contain nor block noise
    • They get in the way and are a waste of space
  • Offices, slight better but still bad
    • They can contain and block noise
    • But they are a terribly inefficient use of space
    • Stifling to collaboration and fascist
  • The best alternative, open floor plans
    • Types of open floor plans
      • the blank slate – just tables and chairs
      • moveable walls – rolling or sliding walls/whiteboards used to create separation
      • Team Area / Pit / Bullpen – semi-private partitions, not easily reconfigured
    • Easily reorganized to accommodate configurations to meet project/team needs
    • Very collaborative
    • What about noise and other interruptions?

Picks

John

  • HDMI Switch from Monoprice
  • Using a Raspberry Pi connected to a TV as your “workboard”

Jason

  • Incentivize Us Properly Please – Fun Game from Agile2014 where you can buy a “Team Fun Zone” or other rewards for your team / company environment
  • Since we talk a lot about conferences – Check This Out – a listing of the Top 50 Lean / Agile / Kanban Conferences
  • More Conference Fun – join ThisAgileLife in Boston at the Agile Games conferences – submit an idea for a workshop or game, we’re taking submissions to put on our program

Amos

  • Gimbal Beacon
  • My Coffee Profile Tessel Project
  • Let your yes be yes and your no be no

item.title: Ep. 69 – Wookiees and Cookies (Ops. Review & Incentives)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, December 28th, 2014. Hosts: Jason Tice, Craig Buchek and Amos King Discussion Raising our Podcast Assurance – Thanks for listening to help us raise our podcast assurance level – episode 69 was recorded without assistance from John – like a good agile team, we want to ensure we don’t have to rely on a […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, December 28th, 2014.

Hosts: Jason Tice, Craig Buchek and Amos King

Discussion

Raising our Podcast Assurance – Thanks for listening to help us raise our podcast assurance level – episode 69 was recorded without assistance from John – like a good agile team, we want to ensure we don’t have to rely on a single podcast member to record an episode, just like a good agile shouldn’t be dependent on a single team member to do a build – we value listener feedback on the podcast.

Operations Review Incentives – Let’s talk about incentives – Jason shares a story where a pizza party was awarded by popular vote for the “most compelling” presentation at a recent Operations Review meeting – Operations Review is a practice recommended by David Anderson where teams share improvements they are implementing to their processes and how results from those improvements / changes are being measured – all in attendance at the Operations Review meeting got to vote for the most compelling presentation – the winner received a pizza party to share with their team.

DEBATE: Carrots & Sticks – Amos, Craig and Jason engaged in a fiery debate on whether or not this was instance of what Daniel Pink calls “Carrot & Stick” rewards which over time result in lower quality of work being performed even if the reward is sustained – there was discussion whether the same tactics used to motivate the sea lions to perform at the zoo should be used within the workplace – the outcome of the debate was inconclusive; however, discussion yielded some suggestions for perhaps improved incentives for future Operations Review sessions.

Oreo Cookies – Craig described an “Oreo Cookie” pattern as a combination of incentive and constructive criticism to yield improvement – provide a compliment, then provide a suggestion or element of constructive criticism, then close with a final compliment – Amos suggested that verbal complements, the opportunity to receive feedback from others or handwritten notes from a colleague thanking them for their support and/or collaboration would be more effective incentives than offering a “pizza party”.

2014 Appreciations – Amos, Craig, and Jason put their suggestions into practice and closed out Episode 69 offering appreciations to many who have supported ThisAgileLife throughout 2014 – listen in to hear who was recognized.

Books mentioned by Craig, Amos and Jason during discussion:

  • Drive by Daniel Pink
  • Punished by Rewards by Alfie Kohn
  • Kanban by David Anderson

Picks

Amos

  • Hate for Sextro giving me Serial to listen
  • http://tessel.io – Node js, wifi enabled micro controller
  • http://adafruit.com – “People who are really serious about software should make their own hardware.” – Alan Kay

Craig

  • ThoughtWorks’ Technology Radar
    • And consider writing your own.
  • tsundoku – buying books and not reading them; letting unread books pile up.
  • Ship of Theseus – a thought experiment that raises the question of whether an object which has had all of its components replaced remains fundamentally the same object.
    • I recently saw something I love, by Donella H. Meadows from “Thinking in Systems”, which answers the question well to my satisfaction:
      • A system is itself, even with substitutions of all its elements, while its interconnections and purposes remain.

Jason

  • “Drive” by Daniel Pick – Use the following link for an antimated summary of the book; however, still read the book, it has lots of good stuff, like how to apply the ideas in “Drive” for your kids and school – https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u6XAPnuFjJc
  • For the Holidays – Game of the week – A collaboration simulation entitled “Power of 13” – thanks to Paul Boos @paul_boos for sharing –  http://www.slideshare.net/pmboos/power-of-13-a-game-to-illustrate-the-power-of-collaboration
  • Pecha Pecha Nights – a fun way to experience short presentations with 20 slides for 20 seconds each – meetings are held in cities all over the world – http://www.pechakucha.org/
  • Come play our Holiday “What have you learned game” – http://innovationgames.com/game/join?id=748-037-088
  • Agile2015 Submissions now open – don’t delay – submit today – January 17, 2015 is the deadline to submit a session and receive help prior to evaluation.

item.title: Ep. 68 – Just Dance Jason (Collaboration)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, December 14th, 2014. Hosts: John Sextro, Craig Buchek, Nate McKie and Jason Tice Discussion Let’s talk about collaboration in a large group, and what happens to a group’s ability to build / maintain a mental model as it becomes larger. As fodder, Craig, Amos and Jason were discussing at the STL Ruby group on 12/8/2014 […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, December 14th, 2014.

Hosts: John Sextro, Craig Buchek, Nate McKie and Jason Tice

Discussion

Let’s talk about collaboration in a large group, and what happens to a group’s ability to build / maintain a mental model as it becomes larger.

  • As fodder, Craig, Amos and Jason were discussing at the STL Ruby group on 12/8/2014 that the magic number for a good podcast seems to be between 3-4 participants.
    • What is wrong with episodes where we have too many people and episodes where maybe we don’t have enough.

      Jason and Amos at STL Ruby

  • What are some rules of the road/team if you happen to be an outspoken person (aka John or Jason) – maybe John and Jason can share what they do on the podcast (and in real life to ensure they aren’t overwhelming others)
  • What can introverts do if they feel they are being overwhelmed in a large setting by the bloviators?
  • Another concept to talk about: the more people there are, the more likely factions develop within the team.
  • What practices can be done to help a team measure if it is collaborating well?
  • Should we even worry about measuring the effectiveness of collaborating in the first place?
  • What practices can be put in place to help a team (regardless of size) improve how it collaborates?

Picks

Jason

  • For the Holidays – Game of the week – The Innovation Games Visual Collaboration Platform – there’s a free version if you want to try before you buy – www.innovationgames.com
  • Agile2015 Submissions now open – don’t delay – submit today –
  • Visual Debriefing with Dr. Roger Greenaway

Nate

  • Hours – Time Tracking app for consultants
  • Dixit – Creative board game that can also be a retro game tool

Craig

  • Industry conferences (check out our list of Agile conferences)
  • My RubyConf 2014 talk, “Ruby Idioms You Aren’t Using Yet”
    • Slides
    • Video (not posted yet)
  • Public speaking – local user groups, regional conferences, (inter)national conferences

John

  • Day One, Journaling App
  • Serial, Podcast

item.title: Ep. 67 – Death by Charts (Code Coverage)
