item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, November 23rd, 2014.

Hosts: John Sextro, Lee McCauley and Jason Tice

Discussion

The holy practice of measuring code coverage:

http://www.stickyminds.com/article/code-coverage-silver-bullet

  • Without code coverage, how do you know if you are writing enough tests?

    Jason speaking at St. Louis Limited WIP Society

  • Test First vs. Test Driven vs. Unit Testing
  • The Wall of Shame
  • Implementing a rule requiring a certain percentage of test coverage for a code base.
  • Suppose I’m an “Application Development Manager” (yes there are people with that job, it is a real job) and I have teams that have different views / practices about testing, what’s wrong with having a baseline level of testing that I would mandate to promote software assurance as part of my job as the ADM is managing risk on behalf of the business in the software they are investing in.
  • The MBA approach to code coverage
  • Starting with a code coverage number can be helpful in some situations, but isn’t a good idea long term.
  • Having confidence in your code
  • Assuring quality code

Picks

Lee

  • Introduction to Test Driven Development (TDD). By @scottwambler
  • http://www.testdriven.com/

Jason

  • Is Code Coverage a Silver Bullet – http://www.stickyminds.com/article/code-coverage-silver-bullet
  • For the Holidays – I’m going recommend fun agile games that will help your team improve – let’s start with – “Protection Poker” by Laurie Williams – http://collaboration.csc.ncsu.edu/laurie/Security/ProtectionPoker/

John

  • Boomerang
  • Google, “Go to the Gemba” and read

item.title: Ep. 66 – Standups
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, November 16th, 2014. Hosts: John Sextro Discussion Life Emailing listeners Contacted 11 listeners, only heard back from Rob Park Effective standups Purpose all about communication and commitment not about status updates to management Mechanics everyone stands, everyone (unless you have medical condition) congregate around your workboard has to last 15 minutes or less, 1 […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, November 16th, 2014.

Hosts: John Sextro

Discussion

  • Life
  • Emailing listeners
    • Contacted 11 listeners, only heard back from Rob Park
  • Effective standups
    • Purpose
      • all about communication and commitment
      • not about status updates to management
    • Mechanics
      • everyone stands, everyone (unless you have medical condition)
      • congregate around your workboard
      • has to last 15 minutes or less, 1 minute per person is a long time
        • if you don’t believe time yourself and try to talk for 1 minute about a single topic
      • start at the same time every morning
        • its a good idea to choose a time that is 30 minutes to an hour after the person that arrives the latest to the office gets in.
        • this gives everyone a chance to get settled in and begin work
      • walk the board or not
        • if your team is focused on the right things they will always be talking to the board.
      • the order
        • going around in a predictable pattern puts people to sleep
        • mix it up to keep everyone on their toes
      • avoid questions
        • if you hear something that you’d like more information about, mention to that person that you’d like to find out more after standup
    • Communication and Commitment
      • it helps to prepare yourself before hand to refresh your memory and focus on your accomplishments
        • if I haven’t done this I often freeze in the moment and forget something key that I wanted to communicate
      • I like to answer the 3 questions in this order, yesterday, today, blockers
      • mention days off, etc.
      • focus on accomplishments, not activities
        • attending a meeting is an activity, not an accomplishment
        • mentioning that you attended a meeting is like saying I worked at my computer for 4 hours
        • what was accomplished via your attendance at the meeting
        • what was accomplished via the convening of the meeting
        • If you can think of an accomplishment from the meeting then you should really consider why you attended
        • In the future consider this before attending a meeting, “Tomorrow morning what will I say was accomplished?”  If you can’t come up with anything then skip the meeting.
        • Caveat: of course there are some meetings that you just can’t skip, like those you are required by management to attend.
          • Just don’t mention those.
      • what happens when I didn’t accomplish what I committed to accomplish
      • Making your commitment
        • Standing before the team to make a promise
        • I don’t want to let down the team
        • Example
          • “Today I will complete the story I pulled last evening”
          • “Today I will assist with the grooming of the backlog”
          • “Today I will help Amos complete the updates to our wiki page cataloging our client api”
          • “Today Craig and I are going to pair on the story Craig pulled while working with Lee yesterday afternoon.”
        • Don’t overcommit yourself, be realistic, maybe even a little pesimistic
          • You don’t want to have to regularly explain to the team why you couldn’t complete what you committed yourself to complete
      • Blockers
        • What’s the blocker and what it is blocking?
        • Who can help clear the block?
        • If you don’t know what to do next, ask to talk more about the blocker at the end of the meeting
    • Pro tips
      • rotate responsibility of kicking off standup
        • if you’re the leader stand up but don’t say anything, see how long everyone else stands there before self organizing.  they quickly get the hint.
      • if everyone keeps looking at the scrum master/lead you should step back or stand in a place that makes it hard to see you
        • my friend Jim Cakalic recommended standing behind or out of the person’s visual field.
      • use a little plastic toy as a team mascot and let everyone pass it around like a hot potato.  the person holding the toy is the one to speak next.
      • Make it a team norm or stand up rule that anyone can suggest that we quickly end a discuss that is taking too long
        • In standup we want speed over verboseness
        • “Let’s discuss this further after stand up.”
        • Invite anyone that wants to participate in the conversation to stick around
      • People arriving late for standup, implement a stand up rule that you have to sing your countries national anthem if you arrive late.
      • Be wary of the same update day after day. this is indicative of problem the team needs to address.
      • Ask someone to summarize the teams accomplishments and commitments for the day.

Picks

Share your picks with us on twitter.  Tweet your pick to @thisagilelife #pick.  We’ll retweet you and share with our community.

Code Reviews Do you need to do code reviews when pairing? How much time should you spend on a code review? What are the mechanics for a code review? What if the code review fails? The Checklist Manifesto Code Review […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, November 2nd, 2014.

Hosts: John Sextro, Craig Buchek, Jason Tice

Discussion

  • College/University what they should teach?
  • Code Reviews
    • Do you need to do code reviews when pairing?
    • How much time should you spend on a code review?
    • What are the mechanics for a code review?
      • What if the code review fails?
      • The Checklist Manifesto
    • Code Review Column or part of Definition of Done?
    • Importance of Unit Tests in running a code review
    • Don’t Increase Tech Debt
    • Past episode of This Agile Life dealing with people problems.
    • Some ideas on what to include in a code review checklist

Picks

John (@johnsextro)

  • Conferences Page on ThisAgileLife.com

Craig (@craigbuchek)

  • Password manager
    • 1Password (kind of expensive, but good)
    • LastPass (YubiKey integration)
    • Mitro (open source)
  • +1 on local user groups
    • Go to learn something new
    • Meet new interesting people
    • “Network”
    • Attend the informal meeting after the meeting — that’s the interesting part
    • Volunteer to give a presentation — you’ll learn a lot

Jason (@theagilefactor)

  • BetaMax – Cool Tool to record and playback HTTP traffic for testing and test automation
  • Local User Groups – make yourself a goal for 2015 to attend a local user group in your area – Tweet us at @thisagilelife about it.

item.title: Ep. 64 – Anything that is Sacred is Not Agile (Scrum)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, October 5th, 2014. Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice Discussion Why Scrum Should Basically Just Die in a Fire by Giles Bowkett The estimation process in Scrum, planning poker combined with the inevitable technical discussions is broken. Agile values communication, why do we limit the technical discussions that always occur during estimation? Standups don’t […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, October 5th, 2014.

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek, Lee McCauley, Jason Tice

Discussion

Why Scrum Should Basically Just Die in a Fire by Giles Bowkett

  • The estimation process in Scrum, planning poker combined with the inevitable technical discussions is broken.
    • Agile values communication, why do we limit the technical discussions that always occur during estimation?
  • Standups don’t work because they always devolve into hour long meetings and what is worse is that the managers always find a way to sit down while the rest of us are left standing.
  • “Sprints” fly in the face of agility.  Agility espouses sustainable pace and there is no such thing as a sustainable sprint.
  • Scrum devalues measuring progress via working software because we track velocity as a metric.
  • “Scrum…tries to enhance the accountability of a field of work [software development] where both failure and success are obvious to the naked eye.”
  • Look at Marketing…they can’t measure their worth so neither should we.

Picks

John (@johnsextro)

  • Listener Shoutouts: Rob Jago, Tom Woundy, Firoj Shaikh

Craig (@craigbuchek)

  • Evidence Based Scheduling
    • How to use velocity properly and predictively.
  • This is why you never end up hiring good developers
    • I like what she says about “team fit”.

Amos (@adkron)

  • Wickham House – hand made bow ties – Jeremy McAnally from Mandiant(SP?) + Wife
  • WTF – is this a Matt Philip pic – Philip would love that Boooo!

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Interesting blogs from a guy at GitHub, Zach Holman, http://zachholman.com/

Jason (@theagilefactor)

  • For fun – Poo-Poo Bad ScrumMasters Say from Adam Weisbart (also Chris Sims and Laura Powers) – https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GGbsgs611MM
  • The 3M Post-It App – have some fun iOS 8 and be able to easily capture image of all your favorite post it notes – http://www.post-it.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/PostItNA/Home/Ideas/Plus-App/
  • AgileDC – Tuesday, 10/21/2014 – www.agiledc.org – John is already going, but now I’m going to and will be facilitating “The Last Responsible Moment LEGO Game” a fun game that allows teams to safely explore the risks and rewards of putting of decisions and work until the “last responsible moment”

item.title: Episode 63 – A Team of A-Holes (Servant Leadership)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, September 21st, 2014. Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek, Lee McCauley Discussion Demystifying Servant Leadership What is it, really? A concept centuries old that was described with this term by Robert Greenleaf in his 1970 essay titled, “The Servant as Leader.” Metaphor for servant leadership — Jesus Christ Setting aside religion, from a historical context; Jesus was a […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, September 21st, 2014.

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek, Lee McCauley

Discussion

Demystifying Servant Leadership

  • What is it, really?
    • A concept centuries old that was described with this term by Robert Greenleaf in his 1970 essay titled, “The Servant as Leader.”
    • Metaphor for servant leadership — Jesus Christ
      • Setting aside religion, from a historical context; Jesus was a famous servant leader.
  • Common Fallacies
    • “Servant Leadership” is a copout that is really code for “I’m going to pay you to do a whole lot of nothing.”
    • It won’t work for my organization/project/team because they require a lot more “command and control.”
  • Characteristics
    • Listening: A servant leader puts the emphasis upon listening effectively to others.
    • Empathy: A servant leader needs to understand others’ feelings and perspectives.
    • Healing: A servant leader helps foster each person’s emotional and spiritual health and wholeness.
    • Awareness: A servant leader understands his or her own values and feelings, strengths and weaknesses.
    • Persuasion: A servant leader influences others through their persuasiveness.
    • Conceptualization: A servant leader needs to integrate present realities and future possibilities.
    • Foresight: A servant leader needs to have a well developed sense of intuition about how the past, present, and future are connected.
    • Stewardship: A servant leader is a steward who holds an organization’s resources in trust for the greater good.
    • Commitment to the growth of people: A servant leader is responsible for serving the needs of others.
    • Building community: A servant leader is to help create a sense of community among people.
    • Our Additions
      • Respect: Believe that everyone on the team is doing the best they can, and you are happy they tried their best – Believe that everyone will succeed.
      • Building everyone on the team into leaders.
      • Maslow’s hierarchy of needs (with respect to the “needs” of others in the “Commitment to growth” item)
      • Passion?
  • All of these Characteristics can consolidated into four attributes which are:
    • Fosters learning
    • Facilitates collaboration
      • Craig’s story about his dad – construction worker foreman as choreographer/conductor
    • Generates trust
    • Acts as the team’s advocate
  • The Retrospective Prime Directive:

Regardless of what we discover, we understand and truly believe that everyone did the best job they could, given what they knew at the time, their skills and abilities, the resources available, and the situation at hand.

  • How can I improve with Servant Leadership
    • Get comfortable with humility
    • Make service your priority
    • Ensure that everyone’s base needs are met
    • Remember that your value comes from what those around you are producing
    • Establish trust with your management and with the project members/team members.
    • Act as a shield or filter for the typical command and control from management.
      • Shit umbrella
      • “You teach best what you most need to learn.” — Bach
      • Take more of the blame, and less of the praise.

Picks

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Leadership in an Agile environment, by Patti Mandarino
  • White paper on Servant Leadership, by Gint Grabauskas

John (@johnsextro)

  • Warby Parker
  • Points the Game

Craig (@craigbuchek)

  • List of Cognitive Biases
  • Trash Your Servers and Burn Your Code: Immutable Infrastructure and Disposable Components

Amos (@adkron)

  • How to Win Friends and Influence People by Dale Carnegie – 4.5 stars with > 2000 reviews on Amazon
  • Docker – Snowflakeless Servers

item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, September 7th, 2014.

Hosts: Jason Tice, John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek

Discussion

  • Bullying in the workplace
    • Tice’s kindergarten metaphor
  • Self-managing work environments and teams
    • Role as a bystander
    • Responding to bullying
      • 1-on-1 Discussion
      • Higher authority/Management
      • Human Resources
  • Safety Checks
    • Stop Work Authority
    • Anonymous tactics
  • What happens over time?
    • Dealing with continued bad behavior
    • ClassDojo
    • The 5 Whys
  • Enforcement
    • Human Resources
    • The law

Picks

Craig (@craigbuchek)

  • Noise-canceling headphones; specifically the Parrot Zik kind.

Amos (@adkron)

  • ncurses – Because retro is cool again, and it is a fun way to have ncurses or big boy graphics optional to make sure your view is decoupled.
  • Learn You Haskell for Great Good
  • Land of LISP

Jason (@theagilefactor)

  • A thought provoking book about what we discussed on this Episode: The No Asshole Rule by Rob Sutton.
  • For those in the St. Louis Missouri area, join me (Tice) for a Lunch-N-Learn hosted by the St. Louis Agile Users Group where we’ll use visual thinking to depict “the perfect user story”. We’ll review many of the components of a well put together user story that we’ve discussed on This Agile Life, but do something to visually depict what each of these components look like in a sketch. The Lunch-N-Learn will be on Friday, September 26, 2014 in the St. Louis Metro area. For more details and to RSVP, click here.

John (@johnsextro)

  • Text Expander
  • Text Expander like utility for Windows
  • AgileDC: Oct. 21.

Hosts: Jason Tice, John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek Discussion Bullying in the workplace Tice's kindergarten metaphor Self-managing work environments and teams Role as a bystander Responding to bullying 1-on-1 Discussion Higher authority/Management Human Resources Safety Checks Stop Work Authority Anonymous tactics What happens over time? Dealing with continued bad behavior ClassDojo The 5 Whys Enforcement Human Resources The law Picks Craig (@craigbuchek) Noise-canceling headphones; specifically the Parrot Zik kind. Amos (@adkron) ncurses - Because retro is cool again, and it is a fun way to have ncurses or big boy graphics optional to make sure your view is decoupled. Learn You Haskell for Great Good Land of LISP Jason (@theagilefactor) A thought provoking book about what we discussed on this Episode: The No Asshole Rule by Rob Sutton. For those in the St. Louis Missouri area, join me (Tice) for a Lunch-N-Learn hosted by the St. Louis Agile Users Group where we’ll use visual thinking to depict “the perfect user story”. We’ll review many of the components of a well put together user story that we’ve discussed on This Agile Life, but do something to visually depict what each of these components look like in a sketch. The Lunch-N-Learn will be on Friday, September 26, 2014 in the St. Louis Metro area. For more details and to RSVP, click here. John (@johnsextro) Text Expander Text Expander like utility for Windows AgileDC: Oct. 21.

item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, August 31, 2014.

Hosts: Jason Tice, Lee McCauley, John Sextro, Amos King

Discussion

  • Episode 56 call out for info on how you capture your retro notes
    • Evernote
    • Bring things up at standup every day
    • Limit the number of things you’re trying to change in the week
    • Kanban Boards
    • Responsibility
  • Facilitators
    • Does a 3rd party facilitator make things better or worse when it comes to the follow through or coming up with meaningful improvements?
    • Facilitator (definition)
  • Following through on retrospectives
    • Shallow Retro
  • Buying in
    • Majority rules?
    • Leveling up the consensus
    • Dealing with hard feelings
    • Circular discussions with no conclusion
    • “Experimentation”
      • Setting perimeters and goals
      • Use metrics to gauge success
      • Feedback
      • Accountability
        • Mastermind Groups
        • Operations Review
    • Coming up with ground rules for a shared understanding
  • Safety checks

Picks

Amos (@adkron)

  • Awkward Stock Photos
  • MasterMind Groups
  • I’m looking for work: contact@binarynoggin.com

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Google Public DNS servers
  • OpenDNS (if you want parental controls to block IPs)
  • Cosmos (reboot) with Neil DeGrasse Tyson is now on Netflix

Jason (@theagilefactor)

John (@johnsextro)

  • Speed read the web with Squirt
  • Getting started with Meditation, 3 posts from Dan Benjamin on Hivelogic

item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, August 24, 2014. Hosts: Jason Tice, Lee McCauley, John Sextro, Amos King Discussion Writing great stories So to get things started about writing great stories, let’s talk about WHO writes them? What’s the lifecycle of a good story look like? 3Cs: Card, Confirmation, Conversation Limiting the size of stories by acceptance criteria. 1, 2 or 3 acceptance […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, August 24, 2014.

Hosts: Jason Tice, Lee McCauley, John Sextro, Amos King

Discussion

  • Writing great stories
  • So to get things started about writing great stories, let’s talk about WHO writes them?
  • What’s the lifecycle of a good story look like?
  • 3Cs: Card, Confirmation, Conversation
  • Limiting the size of stories by acceptance criteria.
  • 1, 2 or 3 acceptance criteria per story
  • Using Given/When/Then gherkin syntax
  • What is we didn’t write stories?
  • Retrospective Book, Good to Great
  • Stories are important because:
    • They give us time to think about what we are doing and how to do it.
    • They allow us to organize the way we are going to work.

Picks

Amos (@adkron)

  • Giant Robots Smashing into other Giant Robots – Sandi Metz’ Rules For Developers
  • RIP 11th Doctor: Matt Smith
  • My company website – I need to hire a designer !!

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • XKCD: Good Code
  • XKCD: Git Commit

Jason (@theagilefactor)

  • Believe it or not, I taught my 4 year old the Scaled Agile Framework
  • “Visual Mojo” – book by Lynn Cazaly who shared one of my favorite workshops on visual thinking and sketching at Agile2014
  • If you do conference calls, you need to watch “A Conference Call in Real Life” Remember: Agile gives preference to face-to-face communication, this is a great example why.

John (@johnsextro)

  • Assembla

item.title: Episode 58 – Splitting, Slicing and Breaking Down Stories
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, August 3, 2014 Hosts: John Sextro Discussion Why I missed the last show. @neil_killick Neil Killick @aritanninen Ari Tanninen Instead of planning poker, try a story slicing session The importance of slicing stories What’s the right size? How to break down stories Metaphors Toaster vs Space shuttle Building a road First build a dirt […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, August 3, 2014

Hosts:  John Sextro

Discussion

Why I missed the last show.

@neil_killick  Neil Killick

@aritanninen Ari Tanninen

Instead of planning poker, try a story slicing session

  • The importance of slicing stories
  • What’s the right size?

How to break down stories

  • Metaphors
    • Toaster vs Space shuttle
    • Building a road
      1. First build a dirt trail
      2. Then add on until you are satisified
    • The Spotify metaphor
      1. skateboard
      2. scooter
      3. bicycle
      4. motorcycle
      5. car
  • The wrong ways
    • view / controller / model or UI / controller / backend
    • across layers of the infrastructure
      1. client
      2. server
      3. database
      4. middleware
  • Example of the right way
    • Story
      1. As the buyer of the product, I want to register my purchase, so that I can receive updates to the product and information about new products similar to the one that I purchased.
      2. Additional requests from the product owner
        1. Don’t spam the user
        2. Guaranteed success of registration.  The buyer of the product won’t stand to go through this process more than once.
        3. Guaranteed delivery of email.  We can’t afford to miss the opportunity to make contact with the buyer.
    • Approach
      1. With your first story, establish a minimal beachhead or presences on each island of technology.
        1. This will help us a learn a lot about the “how” for implementing this story.
        2. For example, maybe you’ll discover that you need to go through a long approval process to request a database or provision an web application container.
        3. We accomplish this by constructing our first story so that we collect a name and email, persist the data and then send an email to acknowledge receipt of the registration.
      2. Layer in the rest of the functionality for the feature while collecting feedback along the way.
        1. Expand the data collected and persisted.
        2. Implement client and server side validations for data collection and persistence.
        3. Ensure guaranteed success of the registration.
        4. Ensure guaranteed delivery of an email.
        5. Implement a mechanism to send daily/weekly email digest to avoid spamming the user.

item.title: Episode 54 – Tice is Immune to Sarcasm (Good to Great)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Released Sunday, June 8, 2014 Hosts: Jason Tice, Lee McCauley, John Sextro Discussion Agile…Good to Great John’s Recommendation Whole team approach Blend your skills Role overloading No single point of failure Easier to swarm and surge Everyone working on the most important thing Eliminate the key person risk Jason’s Recommendation Actually release your software (to PROD) frequently Get […]
item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, June 8, 2014

Hosts:  Jason Tice, Lee McCauley, John Sextro

Discussion

  • Agile…Good to Great
    • John’s Recommendation
      • Whole team approach
        • Blend your skills
        • Role overloading
        • No single point of failure
        • Easier to swarm and surge
        • Everyone working on the most important thing
        • Eliminate the key person risk
    • Jason’s Recommendation
      • Actually release your software (to PROD) frequently
      • Get good at releasing (reduce costs, eliminate delivery risks, automate processes)
      • Plus releasing is hard (we should do hard things more often)
      • Learn all the challenges of maintaining your app in prod (don’t drop the database – Lee)
      • Good to great for developers – sustaining software is different (and often more challenging) then just developing new stuff
      • Get “real feedback” from real users (ensure you built the right thing)
    • Lee’s Recommendation
      • Sweat the small stuff
      • Make sure that all of the little issues that bother your devs are not overlooked
      • Daily habits of the dev team can make your life and their’s much better
      • Once you get the little stuff taken care of, the devs are much more likely to support bigger changes

Picks of the Show

John (@johnsextro)

  • “The Toyota Way”, by Jeffrey Liker

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Robotium – great framework for UI testing on Android

Jason (@theagilefactor)

  • Slack, a new tool (to me at least) for collaboration and messaging
  • Lean Kanban St. Louis – Come join us for monthly events that highlight Lean and Kanban principles that are very similar agile.
  • Next Agile LINC meeting – I’m bring a game to play during the networking session for those that are interested

item.title: Episode 50 – Tice Doesn’t Have a Dirty Bone in His Body (Improving ThisAgileLife)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: This episode sponsored by: Released Sunday, May 25, 2014 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek and Jason Tice Discussion A self-facilitated retrospective on what we have learned doing the last 50 episodes of ThisAgileLife. Planning Planning gives us time to better prepare for the conversation. Without planning, the conversations are more organic. When we have a prepared topic, we should […]
item.content:encoded:
This episode sponsored by:

Released Sunday, May 25, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Craig Buchek and Jason Tice

Discussion

A self-facilitated retrospective on what we have learned doing the last 50 episodes of ThisAgileLife.

  • Planning
    • Planning gives us time to better prepare for the conversation.
    • Without planning, the conversations are more organic.
    • When we have a prepared topic, we should be prepared to discuss the topic.
    • Improvement: Give the hosts 3 to 4 days lead notice on the date and time of the recording and the potential topics.
    • Improvement: Declare the episode type ahead of time so that we can do the necessary preparation for the recording.
    • Improvement: Delegate to @therubyrep.
  • Focus
    • Too often we wonder off of the main topic.
    • Use a “parking lot” to control the conversation.
    • Send us a tweet @thisagilelife to let us know how you feel about our focus and conversation flow.
  • Involving Our Listeners
    • How can we get more listener involvement?
    • Live stream the podcast.
      • IRC Channel
      • Twitter
      • UStream
      • JustinTV
    • Improvement: Engage with the community 48 hours before the scheduled recording time.

Picks of the Show

Craig (@craigbuchek)

  • Spurious Correlations – finds things that have a strong correlation that are probably completely coincidental
  • Rainbow Parentheses – giving each pair of parentheses a different color in your text editor (available for various text editors – Google it)
  • Semantic Highlighting – giving each variable name a different color in your text editor (available for various text editors and programming languages)

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • The Agile Games 2014 – Don’t miss your chance to join 9 presenters, 5 feature games, 5 hours of open space (where you can share the next great agile game and become famous), 1 party at MeadHall in Cambridge, and best of all 1 live episode of ThisAgileLife – all in Boston, MA – June 2-4, 2014.
  • drive.google.com – If you haven’t tried collaborating by having multiple people edit the same document at the same time, you need to try it – endorsed and used by ThisAgileLife – Work Is Going Google.

John (@johnsextro)

  • You are the average of the 5 people with whom you spend the most time (Motivational speaker)
    Consider starting a mastermind group.
  • AgileLINC (In June we are doing a live show on June 18)
  • We now have This Agile Life stickers.  If you want some stickers send us a tweet @thisagilelife

Amos (@adkron)

  • Crisp’s Blog: The Solution to Technical Debt
  • Amos will be in South Carolina May 30 through June 6. He’ll attempt to record a podcast from there.

item.title: Episode 49 – Amos on Fire (Feature Prioritization)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: This episode sponsored by: Released Sunday, May 18, 2014 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King and Jason Tice Discussion Deciding how and what to prioritize for development. In a best-case, user stories have business value (think about the GetKanban game – some stories give you more subscribers – which in turn gives you more revenue – the objective of GetKanban, […]
item.content:encoded:
This episode sponsored by:

Released Sunday, May 18, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King and Jason Tice

Discussion

  • Deciding how and what to prioritize for development.
    • In a best-case, user stories have business value (think about the GetKanban game – some stories give you more subscribers – which in turn gives you more revenue – the objective of GetKanban, like many businesses, is to make money)
    • WSJF (Weighted Shortest Job First) from Lean — Do the thing that provides the most value but requires the least amount of effort (lowest complexity / risk)
    • Amos’s Rating System
      • Show Stopper
      • Game Changer
      • Distraction
    • MoSCoW
      • Must Have
      • Should Have
      • Could Have
      • Won’t Have
    • Commander’s Intent
    • How to determine the value of your features/stories
      • Establish a vision to guide priorities
      • Select most valuable stories based on the vision
      • All other things being equal work the lowest complexity stories first

Picks of the Show

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • ThisAgilelife.com/community encourage Amos to play his Ukulele
  • AgileGames2014 – Don’t delay; register today!
  • GetKanban Game
  • Remember The Future (a game from The InnovationGames collection) – a great way to have teams (or even people) think about what their full potential is, then think about “impediments” to achieving it and “actions” to facilitate improvement.

John (@johnsextro)

  • Agile Ready from Atlassian

Amos (@adkron)

  • My Wife. 9 years on the 28th of this month!
  • Ukulele
  • This Agile Life – The Conference

item.description: This episode sponsored by: Released Sunday, May 11, 2014 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Jason Tice, Lee McCauley Discussion Leadership Organic Growth Power Struggles The Product / Owner Role “The Shit Umbrella” Martyrdom The Good and The Bad of Having a Tight Knit Team Being Friends with Everyone Handling Lateness (changing people’s natural behavioral patterns) Sanctioned Incompetence (keeping someone […]
item.content:encoded:
This episode sponsored by:

Released Sunday, May 11, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Jason Tice, Lee McCauley

Discussion

  • Leadership
    • Organic Growth
    • Power Struggles
    • The Product / Owner Role
    • “The Shit Umbrella”
    • Martyrdom
  • The Good and The Bad of Having a Tight Knit Team
    • Being Friends with Everyone
    • Handling Lateness (changing people’s natural behavioral patterns)
    • Sanctioned Incompetence (keeping someone in a roll where they are underperforming)
    • “Raising the Flag” and Pointing out Underperformance
      • Talking to a person alone vs in front of the group
      • Leadership through fear / intimidation
      • The “Councilor” Persona
  • Team Architecture (Jason)
    • Respect
    • Transparency
    • Trust
    • Shared Vision and Understanding

Picks of the Show

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • A free, online AI class taught by the best in the field: Peter Norvig and Sebastian Thrun

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • Talk-O-Meter – how much time does each person spend talking in a group ($4.99 in the App Store – iOS)
  • Kanban for DevOps by Dominica Degrandis – great tool to introduce Ops staff into the benefits of Kanban
  • Rod Collins – Wiki Management (new book) – how to best manage the collective intelligence of an organization by using wiki’s the “right” way
  • AgileGames 2014 – Derek Wade’s session on building a Team Mental model is an awesome sim using playing cards.

Amos (@adkron)

  • Great Cast of Characters by Amos King
  • Free CS courses online

John (@johnsextro)

  • Kanbana

Discussion

  • DHH Keynote and Article on TDD
    • Talk at RailsConf 2014 (raw feed, starts at 11:30, TDD stuff starts at 35:12)

    • TDD is dead. Long live testing.
  • TDD and Architecture
  • “Looking Better”
  • Writing Tests vs Writing Tests FIRST
    • The Agile Testing Pyramid
  • “Software is more like poetry than physics.”
  • Metrics
    • DHH: Testing like the TSA (code-to-test-ratio)
    • Short-term Cost / Long-term Gain
    • Rails Rescue Projects
    • Qualitative Metrics / Quantitative Metrics

Picks of the Show

Craig (@craigbuchek)

  • Pocket – Save articles to read (or just find) later.
  • Speaking.io – Great tips on public speaking at user groups and conferences.
  • My Blog Response to DHH – TDD Is Alive and Well

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • All my favorite DHH and Jason Fried picks
  • “Rework” – a collection of essays that are quick reads, insightful, and witty about the way to run an organization
  • Basecamp – a different kind of project management tool, that doesn’t keep any metrics, but promotes transparent communication – great for teams that have Email siloing problems – try it for free compliments for 37 Signals
  • AgileGames2014 – Come experience some outstanding community sourced games that will be featured on the second day of the conference by members at-large of the agile games community. Plus, attend a live session of This Agile Life on Monday, June 2, 2014!

Amos (@adkron)

  • VCR – testing

Lee (@agileatheist)

    • Top funny source code comments

Woody Zuill (@woodyzuill)

John (@johnsextro)

  • A slide that epitomizes how to use agile to grow software

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Tynker – iPad app teaching young kids how to code. My 10-year old daughter loves this.

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • The St. Louis Agile Users’ Group – Yes there are 2 agile groups in STL (in addition to STL Agile LINC) – this group meets monthly over in the Metro East near Scott Air Force Base so lots of good discussion about the challenges of agile transformation in the public sector.
  • Dave Snowden comments on SAFe – Read It, and look forward to the discussion on future episode of ThisAgileLife.
  • Agile Games 2014 – June 2014 – sign up today and you can experience a 3 hour Mob Programming workshop with Woody (plus other great sessions).

Booster

Thanks to all of the Boosters that supported the podcast by purchasing a “People Work Here” t-shirt.

  • Travis Meisenheimer

  • Duke Matlock
  • Brian Haggard
  • Thomas Bryant

  • Alex Pennace
  • Kyle Stevens
  • Benjamin Kanouse

Show Retrospective

  • Survey Monkey Questionnaire

Personal Coaching Service

John announced a new personal coaching service that he is offering.  2 packages available:

  • $600 / month
    • 1 hour phone/skype call / week.
    • Unlimited email questions / week, with a guaranteed response the same day.
  • $300 / month
    • 20 minute phone/skype call / week.
    • 2 email questions / week, with a guaranteed response within 24 hours.

2 months free when you purchase 12 months of coaching.

Email John for additional details or to get started today!

Sustainable Pace

  • Sometimes doing what you love doesn’t seem like work.
  • Your Health and your relationship with your family must come first.
  • Down time is critical to refill your creative tank.
  • A lot of problems are solved during down time.

item.content:encoded:
Released Sunday, February 23, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Jason Tice and Amos King

“Get It Started” discussion

  • Jason Tice introduces us to a new way to generate conversation on the team using “A to XP: The Agile ABC Book”, by Karen Favazza Spencer
    • We discuss the “N” word from the book, “Narrative”.
      • Telling stories to enrich conversations
      • Metaphors for systems to tell stories about how the system works

Technical Debt

  • When do allow technical debt into the project?
    • Start with a rule of “No technical debt without agreement from the whole team.”
  • When do you pay back tech debt?
  • How do you make sure you will pay it back.
  • 10 Commandments of Egoless Programming

Picks of the Show

John (@jcsextro)

  • Code School

Amos (@adkron)

  • I spammed Amos, by Joe Barnes
  • Agile Product Ownership in a Nutshell, Henrik Kniberg

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • Definition of Technical Debt, Martin Fowler
  • Fine I’ll make a Product Owner Pick Too, “The Process”

item.content:encoded:
Recorded Monday, February 3, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Nate McKie, Dr. Lee McCauley and Amos King

Splitting Stories

  • Why do we care about splitting a story?

    • Focus
    • Estimation
    • Flexibility
    • Continuous delivery
    • Learning
  • 20 ways to split stories, Bill Wake
  • Story Splitting Flowchart, Richard Lawrence
  • Approaches for splitting stories
    • Password verification field, enter once then enter again
    • Hit the hard part first
    • Border/edge conditions
    • Happy Path
    • So that
    • Validations
    • Higher level Given When Then
    • Spike
  • Dangers of splitting stories
    • Leaving gaps / Tunnel vision
    • Is it possible to be too simplistic?

Picks of the Show

John (@jcsextro)

  • LaunchCodeStL

Amos (@adkron)

  • Smaller is better

Nate (@NateMcKie)

  • Tabletop on YouTube

Lee (@agileatheist)

item.title: Episode 33 – Wanted Posters (Retrospectives)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Monday, January 20, 2014 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, and Ben Linders Getting Value Out of Agile Retrospectives “Getting Value Out of Agile Retrospectives“, by Ben Linders and Luis Gonçalves “With plenty of exercises for your retrospective toolbox, this book will help you to become more proficient in doing retrospectives, and to get more value out of […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Monday, January 20, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, and Ben Linders

Getting Value Out of Agile Retrospectives

“Getting Value Out of Agile Retrospectives“, by Ben Linders and Luis Gonçalves
“With plenty of exercises for your retrospective toolbox, this book will help you to become more proficient in doing retrospectives, and to get more value out of them.”

  • Why would teams do retrospectives
  • Different kinds of retrospective exercises
    • Exercises to build trust
    • Include or exclude managers?
    • Independent facilitator?
      • When to use the team and when to use independent facilitator
      • Some of the best retros just happen when the team decides they are needed.
      • Switching internal facilitators often
    • Car brand, what would you like to be that car brand?
    • Focus on getting better at something you are good at.
    • Perfection game
  • What can you improve using retrospectives
  • How often should teams have retrospectives
  • Our favorite Retrospective Game  to facilitate and what it focuses on.
    • Sextro – Radar exercise
    • Amos – Wanted Posters
    • Ben – One word retrospective (when they are having a really hard time with their feelings)

Picks of the Show

Luis Gonçalves (@lgoncalves1979)

Ben Linders (@BenLinders)

  • What should and what shouldn’t an agile *project manager* do?
    • Agile Project Management
    • Managing and Reporting Agile Projects
    • Managing Projects with Agile Team

John (@jcsextro)

  • Retrospectives group on LinkedIn
  • Retrospectives group on Yahoo

Amos (@adkron)

  • Introspectives

item.content:encoded:
Recorded Wednesday, January 15, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Jason Tice and Karen Favazza Spencer

Location, Location, Location

The 3 Faces of Environment

  • You were saying that Agile resonated with you because it reminded you of kindergarten? What’s up with that?
  • But isn’t adult learning different from children’s learning?
  • Can you give us an example of how changing the environment changed behavior?
  • The 3 Faces:
    • Shared Space: Manifest thoughts in real world – physical space
    • Safe Space: Trust & Culture. Group identity – psychological space
    • Story Space: Working Agreements, Processes, Tools & Games – process space

item.title: Episode 31 – Physical versus Digital Work Boards
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Thursday, January 9, 2014 Hosts: John Sextro and Dr. Lee McCauley Pros and Cons of Physical and Digital Work Boards Digital Pros Easily shared and viewed by many Automatic metric capture Cycle Time Cumulative Flow Velocity Trend Analysis Etc. Easy to change the board configuration, maybe Enforces WIP limits Integration with other tools Can serve as a […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Thursday, January 9, 2014

Hosts: John Sextro and Dr. Lee McCauley

Pros and Cons of Physical and Digital Work Boards

Digital Pros

  • Easily shared and viewed by many
  • Automatic metric capture
    • Cycle Time
    • Cumulative Flow
    • Velocity
    • Trend Analysis
    • Etc.
  • Easy to change the board configuration, maybe
  • Enforces WIP limits
  • Integration with other tools
  • Can serve as a knowledge base
    • Attach designs and other artifacts
    • Collect notes and decisions

Digital Cons

  • Lock in to the tools process and/or limitations of the tool
  • Does not handle pairs
  • Can be difficult to change the board and the process

Physical Pros

  • Incredibly flexible and malleable
  • More reward to move the work across the board
  • Fun to decorate the cards with pictures and other glyphs
  • Easily handles special situations with little effort

Physical Cons

  • Harder to collect and report metrics
  • More difficult to share with remote stakeholders
  • Can not easily attach or associate artifacts to the story cards, this may actually increase person to person conversation on the team, so this could net into a positive

Picks of the Show

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Global Game Jam 2014: 48 hours of the most intense coding you’ll ever get. Last year 309 locations worldwide created over 3000 games over one weekend. This year it is being held on January 24 – 26th.
  • Mailvelope: OpenPGP for web mail. Allows you to encrypt and/or sign emails.

John (@jcsextro)

  • 5 Days to your best year ever, from Michael Hyatt,
    Course will close on Jan. 16th. and the discount offer will expire on the same day.

item.title: Episode 30 – People Work Here (2014 Predictions)
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Monday, December 23, 2013 Hosts: John Sextro, Jason Tice and Dr. Lee McCauley 2014 Predictions regarding the Human Side of Agile By Gil Broza, The Human Side of Agile People will still refer to other people as “resources” — even to their own teammates. Nominally Agile organizations will continue to administer performance appraisals that emphasize the […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Monday, December 23, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro, Jason Tice and Dr. Lee McCauley

2014 Predictions regarding the Human Side of Agile

By Gil Broza, The Human Side of Agile

  1. People will still refer to other people as “resources” — even to their own teammates.
  2. Nominally Agile organizations will continue to administer performance appraisals that emphasize the individual and downplay the team.
  3. Technology managers and stakeholders will still assume that their teams ought to develop quality products faster than is realistically possible.
  4. Companies will continue to not train their developers in Agile engineering, because technical execution skill will remain off the radar.
  5. Project managers will still struggle to come up with a good measure of Agile team productivity for their executives, and consultants will continue telling those project managers that they shouldn’t be measuring productivity.
  6. Bad meetings — and complaining about the number of meetings in Agile — will remain the norm.
  7. Cubicles and other sensory-deprivation cells will still dot offices, but there will be fewer of them.
  8. Female programmers and architects will still be unheard of in many organizations.
  9. Consultants will continue arguing over the merits of various methodologies and frameworks, while practitioners — getting more and more confused — will just do whatever their organizations will tolerate.
  10. And… people like me will remain hopeful and driven to change all that!

Picks of the Show

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • www.the-new-deal.org
  • The Human Side of Agile, website and book by Gil Broza
  • Joy Inc – comes out 12/26, preview online now (the story of Menlo Innovations and how they created a joyous, innovative and respectful culture amongst all)

Lee (@agileatheist)

  • Arduino projects
  • Geek Desk, Amos is anticipating the arrival of his new desk

John (@jcsextro)

  • MagicPrefs, a Mac utility for customizing the way your mouse works.

Technology managers and stakeholders will still assume that their teams ought to develop quality products faster than is realistically possible. Companies will continue to not train their developers in Agile engineering, because technical execution skill will remain off the radar. item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Wednesday, December 4, 2013 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, and Lee McCauley What is Too Big for a Team How do you know if your team is too big? Size alone isn’t enough. Can a team be too big? Indicators Stand up takes too long Losing track of stories and vision The larger the team the […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Wednesday, December 4, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, and Lee McCauley

What is Too Big for a Team

  • How do you know if your team is too big?  Size alone isn’t enough.
  • Can a team be too big?
  • Indicators
    • Stand up takes too long
    • Losing track of stories and vision
  • The larger the team the longer it takes the team to gel.
  • Communication is hard on large teams.
    • Communication is key.
  • What can you do when your team gets too big?
    • Act small
    • Be small, split up
    • Scale using something like safe
  • How to split up?
    • By component?
    • By area of expertise?
    • Prod support vs. Feature development
    • Triage team vs. Stable stream of development team
    • Feature teams

Picks of the Show

Lee (@AgileAtheist)

  • An amazing guy with an amazing blog, mkyong.com
  • “Quiet: The Power of Introverts”, by Susan Cain

Amos (@adkron)

  • ScreenFlow, screen recorder for the Mac
  • Git Flow
  • “Don’t Talk to Just Me”, blog post

John (@jcsextro)

  • “Growing Object-Oriented Software, Guided by Tests”, by Steve Freeman and Nat Pryce

item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Tuesday, December 3, 2013 Hosts: John Sextro, Jason Tice, Amos King, and Nate McKie Product Owners What they should and should not be doing on the team Hierarchy of needs from a product owner Product Vision Release Planning (oh no – we’re going to talk about more planning) Backlog Prioritization When they are optional/necessary/unhelpful If a company […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Tuesday, December 3, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro, Jason Tice, Amos King, and Nate McKie

Product Owners

  • What they should and should not be doing on the team
    • Hierarchy of needs from a product owner
      • Product Vision
      • Release Planning (oh no – we’re going to talk about more planning)
      • Backlog Prioritization
  • When they are optional/necessary/unhelpful
    • If a company doesn’t think a project is important enough to dedicate a product owner, then they aren’t serious about the project.
  • What it takes to be a good one.
    • Fully embraced the concepts of thin vertical slice and minimal marketable feature.
    • Desire for high level of engagement as a full member of the team
    • The Jeff “Cheezy” Morgan skit on Product Owners
  • Play / facilitate InnovationGames to build rapport / trust with stakeholders then use info gathered during games to envision features / stories (this takes a lot of time, but it works).

Picks of the Show

Jason (@TheAgileFactor)

  • Discover to Deliver – Ellen Gottesdiener book on product planning (highly relevant for product owners)
  • STL Limited WIP Society – 1 year anniversary celebration on Monday, December 16, 2013 – details on Meetup
  • Although Thanksgiving has passed, there is nothing stopping anyone from continuing to have an agile THANKSgiving celebration amongst their team / colleagues

Amos (@adkron)

  • Automated User Acceptance Testing
  • Code retreat
  • Alfred

John (@jcsextro)

  • Scrum Poker, iTunes, Google Play Store

Nate (@NateMcKie)

  • ControlPlane – reconfigure your Mac depending on your location

item.content:encoded:
Recorded Monday, November 11, 2013

Hosts: Jason Tice, Amos King, Craig Buchek and Nate McKie

NoEstimates and Metrics

  • Do Amos and Jason share the same opinion on noestimates?
  • How can teams use metrics effeciently?
  • Should you compare metrics across teams?
  • Last responsible moment to track metrics vs. the importance of trending.
  • Tools used, metrics gather and how they are used.

Continuous Improvement

  • The perspective of the C-Level Executive
  • Why continuous improvement is hard.
  • Retrospectives are the fourth most common practice according to the 2014 State of Agile Survey.

Engineering Practices

  • Continuous deployment and frequent releases.
  • The road to production via frequently delivery of working, minimal marketable features.
  • Increasing the number of times you deploy reduces risk.
  • Feature toggles to reduce risk.
  • Features toggles as a feature.

Picks of the Show

Jason

 

Amos

 

Nate

 

Craig

item.title: Episode 23 – Overloading Yoga Positions
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Wednesday, November 6, 2013 Hosts: John Sextro, Dr. Lee McCauley, and Jason Tice Role Overloading What does role overloading mean to you? Swarming / the ‘Whole Team Approach’. Does it have a positive or negative connotation? The positive and the negative of the definition. Negative: When one person tries to become a super hero by […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Wednesday, November 6, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro, Dr. Lee McCauley, and Jason Tice

Role Overloading

  • What does role overloading mean to you?
    • Swarming / the ‘Whole Team Approach’.
    • Does it have a positive or negative connotation?
  • The positive and the negative of the definition.
    • Negative: When one person tries to become a super hero by doing everything.
    • Negative: Filling in when a team is understaffed.
    • Negative: When people try to do too much and end up doing nothing well.
    • Positive: People swarming to get work done as a team.
    • Positive: People pushing their comfort level to expand their skills and add facets to their skill profile.
  • Revisiting the concept of the T-Shaped Person
  • Risk vs. Reward when role overloading
    • Potential for errors vs. making forward progress.
    • It’s better to make small amounts of progress rather than no progress.
    • It’s better to make small amounts of progress rather than creating additional work in progress.
  • Can metrics be used to help manage and assess the success of role overloading?
  • Mob programming.  http://mobprogramming.org
  • A game to demonstrate the benefits of role overloading.

Picks of the Show

John

  • Asana, a team based task management system

Lee

  • TastyCupcakes.org, great agile retrospecitve activities

Jason

  • agilekindergarten.com, go buy the book “A to XP: The Agile ABC Book”

  • MobProgramming.org, go try a mob and let us know what you think

  • And of course LeanKit – @LeanKit

Recorded Tuesday, October 22, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro and Jason Tice

Game – Turn Table

Modification of game developed by Roger Greenway

  • Discuss thoughts and ideas you’ve had today regarding your agile process.
  • Everyone gets a turn.

No Estimates

  • Estimates and Affinity Estimation / Mapping presentation.
    • St. Louis Agile Linc, http://www.linkedin.com/groups/St-Louis-Agile-LINC-4881116
    • How do you use Affinity Estimation when you are a new team?
  • Whole Team approach, favor the soccer team style over the America football style of teamwork.
  • The T-shaped person or T-shaped skills
  • Troy McGinnis, http://focusedobjective.com/

  • Book, Management 3.0 by Jurgen Appelo, http://www.management30.com/

  • St. Louis Limited WIP Society

John

  • WSJ Tech Briefing Podcast
  • Book, Lean Software Development Agile Toolkit by Tom and Mary Poppendieck

item.description: Recorded Tuesday, July 30, 2013 Hosts: John Sextro, Nate McKie and Craig Bucheck Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley Objections to Agile http://www.forbes.com/sites/stevedenning/2012/04/17/the-case-against-agile-ten-perennial-management-objections/ Agile is only for stars – Busted Agile requires co-location and our staff are geographically dispersed – Plausible Agile only works for small projects and our projects are big – Busted Agile lacks project management […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Tuesday, July 30, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro, Nate McKie and Craig Bucheck
Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley

Objections to Agile

http://www.forbes.com/sites/stevedenning/2012/04/17/the-case-against-agile-ten-perennial-management-objections/

  1. Agile is only for stars – Busted
  2. Agile requires co-location and our staff are geographically dispersed – Plausible
  3. Agile only works for small projects and our projects are big – Busted
  4. Agile lacks project management processes – Busted
    1. Scope Management
    2. Earned Value
  5. Agile is slower (TDD and pairing especially) – Busted
    1. Two people to do 1 person’s work
    2. Writing more code (writing 3x the code)
  6. Our firm’s individual accountability systems don’t fit Agile – Busted

Picks of the Show

Nate

  • Fun with Wolfram Alpha, http://www.businessinsider.com/awesome-things-you-can-do-with-wolfram-alpha-2013-7?op=1
  • Agile makes less waste, http://svprojectmanagement.com/the-most-convincing-reason-to-change-from-waterfall-to-agile

John

  • Using RSS to Facilitate Stand Ups
  • Keeping Time, http://www.agileevidence.com/2010/01/scrum-master-tip-focus-your-efforts.html

Craig

  • Use Cordova (PhoneGap) to build mobile apps using HTML, CSS< and JavaScript
  • Markdown and git for your résumé:
    • Scott Granneman’s post that inspired me
    • My résumé and script to build the various formats

item.content:encoded:
Recorded Tuesday, June 11, 2013

Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Nate McKie,  Matt Korwel, and special guest Florian Motlik from codeship.io
Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley

Continuous Deployment

Continuous Integration, a discussion with Flo Motlik from Codeship.io.  Codeship offers continuous integration / continuous deployment as a service.

  • Why create Codeship?  What problem did you see that you needed to solve?
  • We’ve all heard how “GitHub uses GitHub to build GitHub”, did Codeship or does Codeship use Codeship to build Codeship?
  • What are the advantages to using Codeship?
  • Security/Proprietary concerns

Picks of the Show

Matt K

  • Performing Code katas
  • Pair Programming – My Personal Nightmare

Amos K

  • AirPair.co – Get paid for pairing or get help by pairing
  • #pairwithme – Twitter hashtag, people are tracking and will come work with you.

Nate M

  • Video: Agile Product Ownership in a Nutshell, by Henrik Kniberg 

John

  • Agile Linc meeting in St. Louis this Thursday, June 13 from 6pm to 8:30pm

Behavior Driven Development/Acceptance Test Driven Development

  • What is it?
  • What are the benefits?
  • Does this mean Testers and QA are dead?
  • How do you fit this into your dev process/flow?
  • Do you have to use a tool to do BDD/ATDD?

  • What suggests can you can share with the audience to help them avoid running into problems and help them with the adoption of BDD/ATDD in their flow?

Introducing BDD by Dan North

Retrospectives

  • What is a retrospective?
  • How do you run a retrospective?
  • How to improve your retrospective.

Picks of the Show

Amos

  • MindMeister – Shared mind mapping – http://www.mindmeister.com/
  • Serenity Prayer – just a thought for retrospectives – http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serenity_Prayer

Nate

  • Agile Retrospectives book: http://www.amazon.com/Agile-Retrospectives-Making-Teams-Great/dp/0977616649
  • Email transparency (using mailing lists for knowledge capture): https://stripe.com/blog/email-transparency

Craig

  • Real Software Engineering by Glenn Vanderburg
    • An excellent presentation showing how Agile development fits in as an engineering practice.
    • Has a great exploration of the origin of waterfall, which included a caution NOT to do it that way.
  • ack – A great tool to search for text within a hierarchy of text files.
  • Jevon’s paradox – Increase efficiency can lead to increased consumption of a resource.

Matt

  • http://scrumalliance.org/articles/466-selforganizing-teams-what-and-how
  • http://scrumalliance.org/articles/456-effectiveness-of-group-code-review-in-a-scrum-environment

item.title: Episode 11 – I’d Rather Be Coding
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Tuesday, Jan. 12, 2013 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Nate McKie and Jason Tice Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley Intro Music: Rich Johnson Audio Equipment: Adam Axe What do you do with a non-performing member of an Agile team? People understand what the self-managing whole team approach is, and decide to game it – fly under the […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Tuesday, Jan. 12, 2013
Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King, Nate McKie and Jason Tice
Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley
Intro Music: Rich Johnson
Audio Equipment: Adam Axe

What do you do with a non-performing member of an Agile team?

People understand what the self-managing whole team approach is, and decide to game it – fly under the radar not making strong contributions to the team effort, and there may or may not be a mitigation strategy by which improved performance can be solicited.

This is one of those dirty little secrets where things can break down in Agile and an effective team can very quickly become an ineffective team, as the team unity of effort is overcome by someone who chooses to fly under the bar.

We discuss and provide ideas on how to deal with it person-to-person, team-to-person and when to escalate.

Why do many Agile teams hate measurements?

We know we are trolling you a bit here, but the fact remains that many developers are opposed to the idea of capturing metrics and being compared to others on the team or other teams.  However, metrics are an important part of the continuous improvement process. We discuss how to go about capturing the correct metrics and correctly using them to do continuous improvement on your teams.

Picks of the Show

Nate McKie

  • TDGotchi

John Sextro

  • Estimation is Evil, Ron Jeffries

Jason Tice

  • St. Louis Limited WIP Society via Meetup.com
  • Toastmasters

Amos King

  • Principles for Agile Metrics, Jeff Langr

item.description: Recorded Tuesday, Dec. 18, 2012 Hosts: John Sextro, Matt Korwel, Nate McKie and Jason Tice Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley Intro Music: Rich Johnson Audio Equipment: Adam Axe Agile Requirements Elicitation Who’s involved? Story writing Content Sizing Characteristics of a good story — INVEST I Independent The user story should be self-contained, in a way that there […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Tuesday, Dec. 18, 2012
Hosts: John Sextro, Matt Korwel, Nate McKie and Jason Tice
Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley
Intro Music: Rich Johnson
Audio Equipment: Adam Axe

Agile Requirements

  • Elicitation
    • Who’s involved?
  • Story writing
    • Content
    • Sizing
    • Characteristics of a good story — INVEST
I Independent The user story should be self-contained, in a way that there is no inherent dependency on another user story.
N Negotiable User stories, up until they are part of an iteration, can always be changed and rewritten.
V Valuable A user story must deliver value to the end user.
E Estimable You must always be able to estimate the size of a user story.
S Sized appropriately or Small User stories should not be so big as to become impossible to plan/task/prioritize with a certain level of certainty.
T Testable The user story or its related description must provide the necessary information to make test development possible
  • Timing
    • How far in advance?
    • Can you collect requirements too far in advance?
  • Who collects the requirements/writes user stories? BA, Devs, QA, Product Owner, Tech Lead?
    • Requirement Hierarchy:
    • Epics
    • Feature
    • Minimal Marketable Feature
    • Story
    • Task
  • Prioritization
    • How do we know what to work on first?
    • Attributes to consider:
      • Business value
      • Risk
      • Architectural importance
      • Delivery deadlines/expectations
  • User Acceptance of stories delivered
    • Traceability
    • Quality Assurance

Picks of the Show

Nate McKie

  • Dave Snowden’s Cynefin framework

John Sextro

  • User Stories Resource Kit from Rally

Jason Tice

  • Real Life Applications of TimeBoxing – Potty Training For Your 3 Year Old

Matt Korwel

  • http://scrumalliance.org/articles/466-selforganizing-teams-what-and-how
  • http://signalr.net/

item.title: Episode 9 – Agile Immaturiy
item.dc:creator: john.sextro@gmail.com (John Sextro)
item.description: Recorded Tuesday, Dec. 18, 2012 Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King and Jason Tice Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley Intro Music: Rich Johnson Audio Equipment: Adam Axe Agile Maturity I happen to know of an unnamed very large IT Enterprise that is interested in assessing how effective different efforts within their Enterprise are at employing the principles and […]
item.content:encoded:
Recorded Tuesday, Dec. 18, 2012
Hosts: John Sextro, Amos King and Jason Tice
Audio Engineer and Post-Production: Dr. Lee McCauley
Intro Music: Rich Johnson
Audio Equipment: Adam Axe

Agile Maturity

I happen to know of an unnamed very large IT Enterprise that is interested in assessing how effective different efforts within their Enterprise are at employing the principles and practices of Agile.  The Enterprise in question seeks to use Agile Maturity assessment data to determine which efforts are more aligned to its over-arching IT Strategy, which calls out “increased adoption of Agile techniques” as a key strategic goal.  Unfortunately due to ever-present budget constraints, such evaluation data may shift funding to those efforts that are experiencing greater success in “becoming Agile” and aligning to the stated IT strategy, and reduce/eliminate funding for efforts who have struggled to achieve an Agile transformation and/or those efforts that have simply said “we’re not doing that Agile stuff”.

Within the Agile community, there is much debate about the “good” and “bad” of Agile Maturity Assessment criteria – as well as where the Agile Maturity data can be used for both “good” or “bad” decisions.

  • Different thoughts about how you can measure the maturity of Agile within both individual teams, and between teams?
  • The good & bad things that can come from collecting Agile maturity data – does collection and use of quantitative data for decision making regarding the ‘effectiveness’ of Agile teams contradict the spirit and intent behind the tenants of the Agile Manifesto

Picks of the Show

Amos King

  • Keep a programming journal
  • Resume from your GitHub activity http://resume.github.com
  • Amos’ Programming Challenge – spend the next couple of weeks with no method returning nil or a null object. How does that change your code?

John Sextro

  • Retrospectives app for iOS

Jason Tice

  • 12 Days of #Agile Christmas
